soln_description:
44. (2007.05.02) Simplify: After removing the denominator and rearranging, the original expression is equivalent to
$$\begin{array}{l}
9\left[36\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{3}-24\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2} \sum b c+3 \sum a^{2} \sum b^{2} c^{2}+18 a b c \sum a \sum a^{2}-\right. \\
\left.2 \sum b^{3} c^{3}+4 a b c \sum a^{3}-7 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}\right] \geqslant \\
8 \sum a^{2}\left[33\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2}-14 \sum a^{2} \sum b c+\sum b^{2} c^{2}+6 a b c \sum a\right] \Leftrightarrow \\
60\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{3}-104\left(\sum a^{2}\right)^{2} \sum b c+19 \sum a^{2} \sum b^{2} c^{2}+114 a b c \sum a \sum a^{2}- \\
18 \sum b^{3} c^{3}+36 a b c \sum a^{3}-63 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2} \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

Let $s_{1}=\sum a=1, s_{2}=\sum b c, s_{3}=a b c$, substitute into the above expression, and note that $\sum a^{2}=s_{1}^{2}-$ $2 s_{2}, \sum a^{3}=s_{1}^{3}-3 s_{1} s_{2}+3 s_{3}, \sum b^{2} c^{2}=s_{2}^{2}-2 s_{1} s_{3}$, we get
$$60-464 s_{2}+1155 s_{2}^{2}-952 s_{2}^{3}+112 s_{3}-206 s_{2} s_{3}-9 s_{3}^{2} \geqslant 0$$

Let $\omega=\sqrt{1-3 s_{2}}$, i.e., $s_{2}=\frac{1-\omega^{2}}{3}$, by Theorem 2 Corollary 3 in the appendix of the last chapter "Application of Basic Inequalities to Prove Inequalities", we have $s_{3} \geqslant \frac{1-3 \omega^{2}-2 \omega^{3}}{27}$. Since it is easy to prove
$$\begin{aligned}
112 s_{3}-206 s_{2} s_{3}-9 s_{3}^{2} \geqslant & 112 \cdot \frac{1-3 \omega^{2}-2 \omega^{3}}{27}-206 s_{2} \cdot \frac{1-3 \omega^{2}-2 \omega^{3}}{27}- \\
& 9 \cdot\left(\frac{1-3 \omega^{2}-2 \omega^{3}}{27}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, to prove that (1) holds, it is sufficient to prove
$$\begin{array}{l}
60-\frac{464\left(1-\omega^{2}\right)}{3}+\frac{1155\left(1-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}}{9}-\frac{952\left(1-\omega^{2}\right)^{3}}{27}+ \\
{\left[112-\frac{206\left(1-\omega^{2}\right)}{3}\right] \cdot \frac{1-3 \omega^{2}-2 \omega^{3}}{27}-9\left(\frac{1-3 \omega^{2}-2 \omega^{3}}{27}\right)^{2} \geqslant 0}
\end{array}$$

After rearranging, we get
$$\begin{array}{l}
\omega^{2}\left(32-64 \omega+300 \omega^{2}-106 \omega^{3}+713 \omega^{4}\right) \geqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
\omega^{2}\left[32(1-\omega)^{2}+\omega^{2}\left(268-106 \omega+713 \omega^{2}\right)\right] \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

This inequality is clearly true, hence (1) holds, and the original proposition is proved.
informal_statement:
44. Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative numbers such that $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1$. Prove that
$$\frac{1}{3+a^{2}-2 b c}+\frac{1}{3+b^{2}-2 c a}+\frac{1}{3+c^{2}-2 a b} \leqslant \frac{9}{8}$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 44. Let $a, b, c$ be non-negative numbers such that $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1$. Prove that
$$\frac{1}{3+a^{2}-2 b c}+\frac{1}{3+b^{2}-2 c a}+\frac{1}{3+c^{2}-2 a b} \leqslant \frac{9}{8}$$ -/
theorem inequalities_600673 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 ‚â§ a) (hb : 0 ‚â§ b) (hc : 0 ‚â§ c)
    (h : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 1) :
    9 / 8 ‚â• 1 / (3 + a^2 - 2 * b * c) + 1 / (3 + b^2 - 2 * c * a) +
            1 / (3 + c^2 - 2 * a * b) := by

soln_description:
Note that all roots of our equations are non-zero, since the free terms are not equal to zero.

Let $p$ be a common root of the first two equations. Then

$0=b\left(a p^{11}+b p^{4}+c\right)-a\left(b p^{11}+c p^{4}+a\right)=p^{4}\left(b^{2}-a c\right)-\left(a^{2}-b c\right), \quad 0=b\left(b p^{11}+c p^{4}+a\right)-c\left(a p^{11}+b p^{4}+c\right)=p^{11}\left(b^{2}-\right.$ $a c)-\left(c^{2}-a b\right)$.

From this it follows that if one of the numbers $A=a^{2}-b c, B=b^{2}-a c, C=c^{2}-a b$ is zero, then all three are zero. But then

$a / b=b / c=c / a$, and since the product of these numbers is 1, then they are all equal to 1, that is, $a=b=c$. In this case, the statement of the problem is obvious.

Otherwise, all three numbers $A, B, C$ are non-zero. Then $p^{4}=A / B, p^{11}=C / B$.

Let $q$ be a common root of the second and third, and $r$ be a common root of the third and first equations. Similarly, we get $q^{4}=B / C$, hence $p^{11} q^{4}=1$. Similarly, we obtain the equalities $q^{11} r^{4}=1, r^{11} p^{4}=1$. From this, $p^{11^{3}}=q^{-4 \cdot 11^{2}}=r^{42 \cdot 11}=p^{-4^{3}}$, therefore, $p=1$. Similarly, $q=r=1$. Thus, 1 is a common root of all three equations.

Remark. The solution can be completed differently. Let $|B|$ be the middle in magnitude of the numbers $|A|,|B|,|C|$. Then one of the numbers $|p|^{4}=|A| /|B|$ and

$|p|^{11}=|C| /|B|$ is not greater than one, and the other is not less than one. Therefore, both are equal to one, that is, $|p|=1$. Hence, $|A|=|B|=|C|$ and $|q|=|r|=|p|=1$. Therefore, two of the numbers $p, q, r$ are equal, say, $p=q$. But then this number is a common root of all three equations.
informal_statement:
Boogonov I.I.

Non-zero numbers $a, b, c$ are such that any two of the three equations $a x^{11} + b x^{4} + c = 0, b x^{11} + c x^{4} + a = 0, c x^{11} + a x^{4} + b = 0$ have a common root. Prove that all three equations have a common root.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Boogonov I.I.

Non-zero numbers $a, b, c$ are such that any two of the three equations $a x^{11} + b x^{4} + c = 0, b x^{11} + c x^{4} + a = 0, c x^{11} + a x^{4} + b = 0$ have a common root. Prove that all three equations have a common root. -/
theorem algebra_225198 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : a ‚â† 0) (hb : b ‚â† 0) (hc : c ‚â† 0)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ x, a * x ^ 11 + b * x ^ 4 + c = 0 ‚àß b * x ^ 11 + c * x ^ 4 + a = 0)
    (h2 : ‚àÉ x, a * x ^ 11 + b * x ^ 4 + c = 0 ‚àß c * x ^ 11 + a * x ^ 4 + b = 0)
    (h3 : ‚àÉ x, b * x ^ 11 + c * x ^ 4 + a = 0 ‚àß c * x ^ 11 + a * x ^ 4 + b = 0) :
    ‚àÉ x, a * x ^ 11 + b * x ^ 4 + c = 0 ‚àß b * x ^ 11 + c * x ^ 4 + a = 0 ‚àß
    c * x ^ 11 + a * x ^ 4 + b = 0 := by

soln_description:
The 75th question,
Solution: First, prove a lemma: If $x, y \in R$, and for any positive integer $n$, we have $[n x]=[n y]$, then $x=y$. Proof of the lemma: In fact, according to the condition, for any positive integer $n$, we have $ny - 22$, and $A(\beta) \subseteq A(\alpha)$, then for any positive integer $n$, there exists a positive integer $m$ such that $[n \beta] = [m \alpha]$.
First, take $n=1$, then there exists $k \in Z^{+}$, such that $[\beta] = [k \alpha]$.
We will prove by induction on $n$: For any positive integer $n \in Z^{+}$, we have $[n \beta] = [n k \alpha]$.
When $n=1$, the conclusion is obviously true. Assume the conclusion holds for all positive integers less than $n (n \geq 2)$. Now consider the case of $n$.

Since $[(n k-1) \alpha] + [\alpha] \leq [n k \alpha] \leq [k \alpha] + [(n-1) k \alpha] + 1 = [\beta] + [(n-1) \beta] + 1 \leq [\mathrm{n} \beta] + 1$, hence $[\mathrm{n} \beta] \geq [(n k-1) \alpha] + [\alpha] - 1 > [(n k-1) \alpha]$.

Also, $[(n k+1) \alpha] \geq [k \alpha] + [(n-1) k \alpha] + [\alpha] = [\beta] + [(n-1) \beta] + [\alpha] \geq [n \beta] - 1 + [\alpha] > [n \beta]$, so there must be $[n \beta] = [n k \alpha]$.

According to mathematical induction, for any positive integer $n$, we have $[n \beta] = [n k \alpha]$. Therefore, according to the lemma, $\beta = k \alpha$, thus $\frac{\beta}{\alpha} = k \in Z$.
(2) Next, prove: An irrational number $\alpha$ greater than 1 and less than 2 does not satisfy the condition.
Let $\beta = \frac{\alpha}{2 - \alpha}$, then $\frac{\beta}{\alpha} = \frac{1}{2 - \alpha} \notin Z$. We will prove: $A(\beta) \subseteq A(\alpha)$. That is, we only need to prove: For any positive integer $n$, there exists a positive integer $m$ such that $[n \beta] = [m \alpha]$.

Let $[n \beta] = s$, then $s \leq n \beta = \frac{n \alpha}{2 - \alpha} < s + 1 \Rightarrow 2s - s \alpha \leq n \alpha < 2(s + 1) - (s + 1) \alpha$, rearranging gives $s \leq \frac{(n + s) \alpha}{2} < \frac{(n + s + 1) \alpha}{2} < s + 1$, thus $[n \beta] = s = \left[\frac{(n + s) \alpha}{2}\right] = \left[\frac{(n + s + 1) \alpha}{2}\right]$. Note that $\frac{n + s}{2}$ and $\frac{n + s + 1}{2}$ must include one integer, take this integer as $m$, then $[n \beta] = [m \alpha]$.
In summary, the $\alpha$ that satisfies the condition is all irrational numbers greater than 2.
Note: In fact, when $1 < \alpha < 2$, take $\gamma = \frac{\alpha}{\alpha - 1}$, then $\frac{1}{\alpha} + \frac{1}{\gamma} = 1$, according to the Beatty's theorem, $A(\alpha)$ and $A(\gamma)$ form a partition of $Z^{+}$. Also, $A(\gamma) \subseteq A\left(\frac{\gamma}{2}\right)$, hence $Z^{+} \backslash A\left(\frac{\gamma}{2}\right) \subseteq A(\alpha)$. Then take $\beta = \frac{1}{1 - \frac{2}{\gamma}} = \frac{\alpha}{2 - \alpha}$, according to Beatty's theorem, $A(\beta) = Z^{+} \backslash A\left(\frac{\gamma}{2}\right) \subseteq A(\alpha)$.
informal_statement: The seventy-fifth question: For any positive real number $x$, define the set $A(x)=\left\{[n x] \mid n \in Z^{+}\right\}$. Find all irrational numbers $\alpha$ greater than 1 such that: if a positive real number $\beta$ satisfies $A(\beta) \subseteq A(\alpha)$, then $\frac{\beta}{\alpha}$ is an integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- The seventy-fifth question: For any positive real number $x$, define the set $A(x)=\left\{[n x] \mid n \in Z^{+}\right\}$. Find all irrational numbers $\alpha$ greater than 1 such that: if a positive real number $\beta$ satisfies $A(\beta) \subseteq A(\alpha)$, then $\frac{\beta}{\alpha}$ is an integer. -/
theorem number_theory_181923 (Œ± : ‚Ñù) (hŒ± : Irrational Œ±) (hŒ±1 : Œ± > 1)
    (A : ‚Ñù ‚Üí Set ‚Ñ§) (hA : ‚àÄ x, A x = {n | ‚àÉ m : ‚Ñï, m > 0 ‚àß n = ‚åäm * x‚åã}) :
    (‚àÄ Œ≤ > 0, A Œ≤ ‚äÜ A Œ± ‚Üí ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, Œ≤ / Œ± = k) ‚Üî Œ± > 2 := by

may raise the question: what does this identity have to do with anything? Who knows... The author just felt like writing it.

Answer: for example, $x=120, y=11$.
informal_statement:
910*. Find some solution to the equation

$$
x^{2}-119 y^{2}=1
$$

in natural numbers.
informal_proof:
We want to show that there exist natural numbers $x$ and $y$ such that $x^2 - 119y^2 = 1$.

We will prove this by construction. Let $x = 120$ and $y = 11$. We substitute these values into the left-hand side of the equation:
$$
x^2 - 119y^2 = 120^2 - 119 \cdot 11^2
$$
First, we compute the squares:
$$
120^2 = 14400
$$
$$
11^2 = 121
$$
Substituting these back into the expression gives:
$$
14400 - 119 \cdot 121
$$
Next, we compute the product:
$$
119 \cdot 121 = 14399
$$
Finally, we perform the subtraction:
$$
14400 - 14399 = 1
$$
Since substituting $x=120$ and $y=11$ into the equation yields $1=1$, we have found a valid solution in the natural numbers. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 910*. Find some solution to the equation

$$
x^{2}-119 y^{2}=1
$$

in natural numbers. -/
theorem number_theory_115547 : ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï, x ^ 2 - 119 * y ^ 2 = 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_115547 : ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï, x ^ 2 - 119 * y ^ 2 = 1 := by 
  use 120, 11
  all_goals
    norm_num
    <;> omega

soln_description:
Answer. $x= \pm \frac{\pi}{6}+\frac{k \pi}{2}, k \in \mathrm{Z}$.

Solution. Transform the right side of the equation:

$\sin x(\sin x-\sin 5 x)=\sin x \cdot(-2 \sin 2 x \cos 3 x)=-\sin 2 x \cdot(2 \sin x \cos 3 x)=-\sin 2 x \cdot(\sin 4 x-\sin 2 x)=$

$$
=-\sin 2 x(2 \sin 2 x \cos 2 x-\sin 2 x)=\sin ^{2} 2 x(1-2 \cos 2 x)=\left(1-\cos ^{2} 2 x\right)(1-2 \cos 2 x)
$$

Let $\cos 2 x=t$. Then the equation takes the form $\left(\frac{9}{4}+3 t\right) \cdot|1-2 t|=(1-2 t)\left(1-t^{2}\right)$. There are three cases.

a) $t=\frac{1}{2}$ is a root of the equation.

b) $t<\frac{1}{2}$. We get $\frac{9}{4}+3 t=-(1-2 t)\left(1-t^{2}\right), \frac{9}{4}+3 t=-1+2 t-t^{2}+2 t^{3}, 2 t^{3}-t^{2}-5 t-\frac{13}{4}=0$. This cubic equation has no real roots that satisfy $t<\frac{1}{2}$.

c) $t>\frac{1}{2}$. We get $\frac{9}{4}+3 t=t^{2}-1, t^{2}-3 t-\frac{13}{4}=0, t=\frac{3 \pm \sqrt{22}}{2}$. The root $t_{1}=\frac{3+\sqrt{22}}{2}$ does not fit, as $t_{1}>1$; the root $t_{2}=\frac{3-\sqrt{22}}{2}$ does not fit, as it does not satisfy the condition $t>\frac{1}{2}$.

In total: $t= \pm \frac{1}{2}, \cos 2 x= \pm \frac{1}{2}, 2 x= \pm \frac{\pi}{3}+k \pi, x= \pm \frac{\pi}{6}+\frac{k \pi}{2}, k \in \mathrm{Z}$.
informal_statement: 2. Solve the equation $\left(3 \cos 2 x+\frac{9}{4}\right) \cdot|1-2 \cos 2 x|=\sin x(\sin x-\sin 5 x)$.

/- 2. Solve the equation $\left(3 \cos 2 x+\frac{9}{4}\right) \cdot|1-2 \cos 2 x|=\sin x(\sin x-\sin 5 x)$. -/

  (3 * cos (2 * x) + 9 / 4) * abs (1 - 2 * cos (2 * x)) = sin x * (sin x - sin (5 * x)) ‚Üî
  ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, x = œÄ / 6 + k * œÄ / 2 := by

soln_description:
1. **Rewrite the given sum**:
   \[
   \sum_{k \in S} \left\lfloor \sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}} \right\rfloor
   \]
   Here, \( S \) is the set of positive square-free integers. We need to evaluate the sum of the greatest integer less than or equal to \( \sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}} \) for all \( k \in S \).

2. **Express the floor function in terms of a double sum**:
   \[
   \left\lfloor \sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}} \right\rfloor = \sum_{i=1}^{\left\lfloor \sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}} \right\rfloor} 1
   \]
   This means we count the number of integers \( i \) such that \( i \leq \sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}} \).

3. **Rewriting the sum**:
   \[
   \sum_{k \in S} \left\lfloor \sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}} \right\rfloor = \sum_{k \in S} \sum_{i=1}^{\left\lfloor \sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}} \right\rfloor} 1
   \]
   This can be interpreted as counting the number of pairs \((k, i)\) such that \( k \in S \) and \( i \leq \sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}} \).

4. **Change the order of summation**:
   Let \( m = k i^2 \). Then \( m \) ranges from 1 to \( 10^{10} \), and \( k \) must be a square-free divisor of \( m \). Therefore, we can rewrite the sum as:
   \[
   \sum_{m=1}^{10^{10}} \sum_{\substack{k \in S \\ k \mid m \\ k \text{ square-free}}} 1
   \]
   Here, \( k \) is a square-free divisor of \( m \).

5. **Count the number of square-free divisors**:
   Each \( m \) has a unique representation as \( k i^2 \) where \( k \) is square-free and \( i \) is an integer. The number of such pairs \((k, i)\) for each \( m \) is exactly 1, because \( k \) and \( i \) are uniquely determined by \( m \).

6. **Sum over all \( m \)**:
   Since each \( m \) from 1 to \( 10^{10} \) contributes exactly 1 to the sum, we have:
   \[
   \sum_{m=1}^{10^{10}} 1 = 10^{10}
   \]

Conclusion:
\[
\boxed{10^{10}}
\]
informal_statement: An integer is square-free if it is not divisible by $a^2$ for any integer $a>1$. Let $S$ be the set of positive square-free integers. Determine, with justification, the value of\[\sum_{k\epsilon S}\left[\sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}}\right]\]where $[x]$ denote the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def isSquareFree (n : ‚Ñï) := ¬¨‚àÉ a > 1, a^2 ‚à£ n

/- An integer is square-free if it is not divisible by $a^2$ for any integer $a>1$. Let $S$ be the set of positive square-free integers. Determine, with justification, the value of\[\sum_{k\epsilon S}\left[\sqrt{\frac{10^{10}}{k}}\right]\]where $[x]$ denote the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$ -/
theorem number_theory_72416 :
    ‚àë·∂† k ‚àà {k | isSquareFree k}, ‚åäReal.sqrt (10^10 / k)‚åã = 10^10 := by

soln_description:
19. (1) $a=0.15, b=30$.
(2) From Table 1, we know that there are 50 premium quality light bulbs, 100 standard quality light bulbs, and 50 defective light bulbs in the sample.
Thus, the ratio of premium quality, standard quality, and defective light bulbs is $50: 100: 50=1: 2: 1$.
Therefore, according to stratified sampling, the number of light bulbs purchased is $n=k+2k+k=4k\left(k \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$.
Thus, the minimum value of $n$ is 4.
(3) All possible values of $X$ are $0, 1, 2, 3$.
By the problem, the probability of purchasing one light bulb and it being defective is $0.1+0.15=0.25$.

Purchasing 3 light bulbs from this batch can be considered as 3 independent repeated trials, thus,
$$
\begin{array}{c}
P(X=0)=\mathrm{C}_{3}^{0}\left(1-\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3}=\frac{27}{64}, \\
P(X=1)=\mathrm{C}_{3}^{1} \frac{1}{4}\left(1-\frac{1}{4}\right)^{2}=\frac{27}{64}, \\
P(X=2)=\mathrm{C}_{3}^{2}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{2}\left(1-\frac{1}{4}\right)=\frac{9}{64}, \\
P(X=3)=\mathrm{C}_{3}^{3}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3}=\frac{1}{64} .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the distribution of the random variable $X$ is as shown in Table 2.
Table 2
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline$X$ & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\
\hline$P$ & $\frac{27}{64}$ & $\frac{27}{64}$ & $\frac{9}{64}$ & $\frac{1}{64}$ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

Thus, the expected value of $X$ is
$$
E(X)=0 \times \frac{27}{64}+1 \times \frac{27}{64}+2 \times \frac{9}{64}+3 \times \frac{1}{64}=\frac{3}{4} .
$$
informal_statement:
19. (12 points) In a certain batch of a certain type of light bulb, 200 samples were randomly selected, and their lifespans were tracked and recorded in a frequency distribution table as shown in Table 1. Based on their lifespan, the light bulbs are classified into three grades: premium, standard, and substandard. Light bulbs with a lifespan of 500 days or more are considered premium, those with a lifespan of less than 300 days are considered substandard, and the rest are considered standard.
Table 1
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Lifespan (days) & Frequency & Relative Frequency \\
\hline$[100,200)$ & 20 & 0.10 \\
\hline$[200,300)$ & 30 & $a$ \\
\hline$[300,400)$ & 70 & 0.35 \\
\hline$[400,500)$ & $b$ & 0.15 \\
\hline$[500,600)$ & 50 & 0.25 \\
\hline Total & 200 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
(1) Based on the data in Table 1, write the values of $a$ and $b$;
(2) A person randomly purchases $n$ ($n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}$) light bulbs from the sample. If the grade distribution of these $n$ light bulbs is the same as that obtained by stratified sampling according to the three grades, find the minimum value of $n$;
(3) A person randomly purchases 3 light bulbs from this batch for use. If the above frequencies are used as probabilities, let $X$ represent the number of substandard light bulbs purchased by this person. Find the distribution of $X$ and its expected value.
informal_proof:
Let `a` and `b` be real numbers satisfying the given conditions. We are given the equation:
\[20a + 30b + 70(1 - a - b) = 200\]
We first simplify this equation through algebraic manipulation. Distributing the `70` across the terms in the parenthesis gives:
\[20a + 30b + 70 - 70a - 70b = 200\]
Combining the terms containing `a` and `b`, we get:
\[(20 - 70)a + (30 - 70)b + 70 = 200\]
\[-50a - 40b + 70 = 200\]
Subtracting 70 from both sides yields:
\[-50a - 40b = 130\]
Finally, multiplying the entire equation by -1/10, we obtain a simpler relation between `a` and `b`:
\[5a + 4b = -13\]
Next, we use the given hypotheses that `0 < a < 1` and `0 < b < 1`. In particular, we know that `a` and `b` are strictly positive.
Since `a > 0`, it follows that `5a > 0`.
Similarly, since `b > 0`, it follows that `4b > 0`.
The sum of two strictly positive numbers must be strictly positive. Therefore, we can conclude that:
\[5a + 4b > 0\]
We have now derived two conflicting results:
1. From the main equation, we found that `5a + 4b = -13`.
2. From the positivity constraints, we found that `5a + 4b > 0`.

It is impossible for a number to be equal to -13 and simultaneously be greater than 0. This means that the initial assumptions are contradictory. Based on the principle of explosion in classical logic, any statement can be proven from a set of contradictory premises. Therefore, the conclusion that `a = 0.15` and `b = 0.25` holds.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 19. (12 points) In a certain batch of a certain type of light bulb, 200 samples were randomly selected, and their lifespans were tracked and recorded in a frequency distribution table as shown in Table 1. Based on their lifespan, the light bulbs are classified into three grades: premium, standard, and substandard. Light bulbs with a lifespan of 500 days or more are considered premium, those with a lifespan of less than 300 days are considered substandard, and the rest are considered standard.
Table 1
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Lifespan (days) & Frequency & Relative Frequency \\
\hline$[100,200)$ & 20 & 0.10 \\
\hline$[200,300)$ & 30 & $a$ \\
\hline$[300,400)$ & 70 & 0.35 \\
\hline$[400,500)$ & $b$ & 0.15 \\
\hline$[500,600)$ & 50 & 0.25 \\
\hline Total & 200 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
(1) Based on the data in Table 1, write the values of $a$ and $b$;
(2) A person randomly purchases $n$ ($n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}$) light bulbs from the sample. If the grade distribution of these $n$ light bulbs is the same as that obtained by stratified sampling according to the three grades, find the minimum value of $n$;
(3) A person randomly purchases 3 light bulbs from this batch for use. If the above frequencies are used as probabilities, let $X$ represent the number of substandard light bulbs purchased by this person. Find the distribution of $X$ and its expected value. -/
theorem algebra_301598 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a ‚àß a < 1) (hb : 0 < b ‚àß b < 1)
    (h : 20 * a + 30 * b + 70 * (1 - a - b) = 200) :
    a = 0.15 ‚àß b = 0.25 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_301598 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a ‚àß a < 1) (hb : 0 < b ‚àß b < 1)
    (h : 20 * a + 30 * b + 70 * (1 - a - b) = 200) :
    a = 0.15 ‚àß b = 0.25 := by
  have h1 : a > 0 := ha.1
  have h2 : a < 1 := ha.2
  have h3 : b > 0 := hb.1
  have h4 : b < 1 := hb.2

  -- Rearrange the equation to derive inconsistency

informal_statement: Determine the polynomial $P(x)$ of degree $4$ that satisfies the following conditions: $P(3)=2$, $P'(3)=0$, $P''(3)=4$, $P'''(3)=2$, and $P''''(3)=6$. Use the Maclaurin series expansion centered at $x=3$ to find $P(x)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine the polynomial $P(x)$ of degree $4$ that satisfies the following conditions: $P(3)=2$, $P'(3)=0$, $P''(3)=4$, $P'''(3)=2$, and $P''''(3)=6$. Use the Maclaurin series expansion centered at $x=3$ to find $P(x)$. -/
theorem algebra_6187 {P : Polynomial ‚Ñù} (hP : P.degree = 4)
    (hP1 : P.eval 3 = 2) (hP2 : P.derivative.eval 3 = 0) (hP3 : P.derivative.derivative.eval 3 = 4)
    (hP4 : P.derivative.derivative.derivative.eval 3 = 2) (hP5 : P.derivative.derivative.derivative.derivative.eval 3 = 6) :
    P = 2 + 2 * (X - 3) ^ 2 + (1 / 3) * (X - 3) ^ 3 + (1 / 4) * (X - 3) ^ 4 := by

soln_description:
„ÄêAnalysis„ÄëFirst, let the original expression be $A=$
$$
6+\frac{5^{2}}{6+\frac{7^{2}}{6+\frac{9^{2}}{x}}}
$$
$\qquad$ , then $x=6+\frac{11^{2}}{6+\cdots}>6$, so $x>6$,
$$
x=6+\frac{11^{2}}{6+\cdots}<6+\frac{11^{2}}{6}<27 \text {, }
$$

When $x=6$,
$$
\text { the original expression }=3+\frac{1^{2}}{6+\frac{3^{2}}{6+\frac{5^{2}}{6+\frac{7^{2}}{6+\frac{9^{2}}{6}}}}}=3+\frac{1^{2}}{6+\frac{3^{2}}{6+\frac{5^{2}}{6+\frac{7^{2}}{39}}}}=3+\frac{1^{2}}{6+\frac{3^{2}}{6+\frac{975}{332}}}=3+\frac{1^{2}}{6+\frac{996}{989}}=3.142,
$$

When $x=27$,
$$
\text { the original expression }=3+\frac{1^{2}}{6+\frac{3^{2}}{6+\frac{5^{2}}{6+\frac{81}{27}}}}=3+\frac{1^{2}}{6+\frac{927}{843}}=3.1408,
$$

Then, $3.142 \times 100=314.2$,
$$
3.1408 \times 100=314.08 \text {, }
$$

Then, $314.08<A \times 100<314.2$, the only integer between them is 314,
Therefore, the integer closest to $A \times 100$ is 314.
The answer is: 314.
informal_statement: 5. (10 points) $A=3+\frac{1^{2}}{6+\frac{3^{2}}{5^{2}}}$, the integer closest to $A \times 100$ is
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. (10 points) $A=3+\frac{1^{2}}{6+\frac{3^{2}}{5^{2}}}$, the integer closest to $A \times 100$ is -/
theorem algebra_279737 {A : ‚Ñù} (hA : A = 3 + (1^2) / (6 + (3^2) / 5^2)) :
    round (A * 100) = 314 := by

soln_description:
4. 1) Solution. Since \(a c+b^{2}-2 x^{4} y^{4}=x^{3} y \cdot x y^{3}+\) \(+x^{4} y^{4}-2 x^{4} y^{4}=0\), the first equality is an identity.

2) Solution. \(a y^{2}+c x^{2}-2 x y b=x^{3} y y^{2}+x y^{3} x^{2}-2 x y x^{2} y^{2}=\) \(=0\).

The equality is an identity.
3) Solution. \(a b c+b^{3}=x^{3} y \cdot x^{2} y^{2} \cdot x y^{3}+x^{6} y^{6}=2 x^{6} y^{6}\).

When \(x=y=0\), this monomial equals zero, and therefore its numerical value is not a positive number. The specified relation does not hold for all values of \(x\) and \(y\).
informal_statement:
4. Prove or disprove that if \(a=x^{3} y, b=x^{2} y^{2}\), \(c=x y^{3}\), then for any \(x\) and \(y\) the following relations hold:
1) \(a c+b^{2}-2 x^{4} y^{4}=0\)
3) \(a b c+b^{3}>0\).
2) \(a y^{2}+c x^{2}=2 x y b\)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Prove or disprove that if \(a=x^{3} y, b=x^{2} y^{2}\), \(c=x y^{3}\), then for any \(x\) and \(y\) the following relations hold:
1) \(a c+b^{2}-2 x^{4} y^{4}=0\)
3) \(a b c+b^{3}>0\).
2) \(a y^{2}+c x^{2}=2 x y b\) -/
theorem algebra_292009 (x y : ‚Ñù) (a b c : ‚Ñù)
    (ha : a = x^3 * y) (hb : b = x^2 * y^2) (hc : c = x * y^3) :
    a * c + b^2 - 2 * x^4 * y^4 = 0 ‚àß
    a * b * c + b^3 > 0 ‚àß
    a * y^2 + c * x^2 = 2 * x * y * b := by

soln_description:
Given the problem, we have
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a^{2}+a c=1, \\
b^{2}+b c=1, \\
c^{2}+a c=3, \\
d^{2}+a d=3 .
\end{array}\right.
$$
(1) + (3) gives $(a+c)^{2}=4 \Rightarrow a+c= \pm 2$.

Thus, we know $a+c \neq 0$.
(3) $\div$ (1) gives $c=3 a$,

so $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=\frac{1}{2}, \\ c=\frac{3}{2}\end{array}\right.$ or $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=-\frac{1}{2}, \\ c=-\frac{3}{2} .\end{array}\right.$
From (2) - (1) we get $(a-b)(a+b+c)=0$,
From (4) - (3) we get $(d-c)(a+d+c)=0$.
$1^{\circ}$ When $a=b, c=d$, we have
$6 a+2 b+3 c+2 d=8 a+5 c= \pm \frac{23}{2}$.
$2^{\circ}$ When $a=b, c \neq d$, from (6) we know $a+d+c=0$, so $6 a+2 b+3 c+2 d=8 a+3 c+2(-a-c)= \pm \frac{9}{2}$.
$3^{\circ}$ When $a \neq b, c=d$, from (5) we know $a+b+c=0$, so $6 a+2 b+3 c+2 d=6 a+2(-a-c)+5 c= \pm \frac{13}{2}$.
$4^{\circ}$ When $a \neq b, c \neq d$, from (5) and (6) we know $a+b+c=0$, $a+c+d=0$, so
$$
\begin{array}{l}
6 a+2 b+3 c+2 d \\
=6 a+2(-a-c)+3 c+2(-a-c)= \pm \frac{1}{2} .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: ‰∏Ä,(20 points) Given that $a, b, c, d$ are all non-zero real numbers. Substituting $x=a$ and $b$ into $y=x^{2}+c x$, the value of $y$ is 1 in both cases; substituting $x=c$ and $d$ into $y=x^{2}+a x$, the value of $y$ is 3 in both cases. Try to find the value of $6 a+2 b+3 c+2 d$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ‰∏Ä,(20 points) Given that $a, b, c, d$ are all non-zero real numbers. Substituting $x=a$ and $b$ into $y=x^{2}+c x$, the value of $y$ is 1 in both cases; substituting $x=c$ and $d$ into $y=x^{2}+a x$, the value of $y$ is 3 in both cases. Try to find the value of $6 a+2 b+3 c+2 d$. -/
theorem algebra_308099 {a b c d : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (hb : b ‚â† 0) (hc : c ‚â† 0) (hd : d ‚â† 0)
    (h1 : (a^2 + c * a) = 1) (h2 : (b^2 + c * b) = 1) (h3 : (c^2 + a * c) = 3)
    (h4 : (d^2 + a * d) = 3) : 6 * a + 2 * b + 3 * c + 2 * d = 1 / 2 ‚à® 6 * a + 2 * b + 3 * c + 2 * d = -1 / 2 := by

soln_description:
a) Subtracting the first equation from the second, we get $x_{4}=x_{1}$. Similarly, $x_{5}=x_{2}, x_{6}=x_{3}, \ldots, x_{3}=x_{100}$. Since 100 is not divisible by 3, it follows that

$x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}=\ldots=x_{100}$

b) Adding all the equations, we get $x+y+z+t=1 / 3(a+b+c+d)$. Subtracting each of the equations from this result, we get the answer

c) Adding all the equations, we get $4 x_{1}=2\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}+a_{4}\right)$. Adding the first two equations and subtracting the last two, we similarly find $x_{2}$. And so on.

d) Let $s=x_{1}+x_{2}+\ldots+x_{n}$. Adding all the equations, we get $1 / 2 n(n+1) s=a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{n}$. Subtracting the second equation from the first, we get

$s-n x_{1}=a_{1}-a_{2}$. Hence, $x_{1}=1 / n\left(s-a_{1}+a_{2}\right)$. The other unknowns are found similarly.

## Answer

a) $(0,0, \ldots, 0)$.

b) $x=1 / 3(a+b+c-2 d), y=1 / 3(a+b-2 c+d), z=1 / 3(a-2 b+c+d), t=1 / 3(b+c+d-2 a)$.

c) $x_{1}=1 / 2\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}+a_{4}\right)$, $x_{2}=1 / 2\left(a_{1}+a_{2}-a_{3}-a_{4}\right), x_{3}=1 / 2\left(a_{1}-a_{2}+a_{3}-a_{4}\right), x_{4}=1 / 2\left(a_{1}-a_{2}-a_{3}+a_{4}\right)$.

d) $x_{1}=\frac{1}{n}\left(\frac{2\left(a_{1}+\ldots+a_{n}\right)}{n(n+1)}-a_{1}+a_{2}\right), x_{2}=\frac{1}{n}\left(\frac{2\left(a_{1}+\ldots+a_{n}\right)}{n(n+1)}-a_{2}+a_{3}\right)$

$x_{n}=\frac{1}{n}\left(\frac{2\left(a_{1}+\ldots+a_{n}\right)}{n(n+1)}-a_{n}+a_{1}\right)$.

Solution. Let $\frac{d y}{d x}=z$, then the given equation can be written as:

$$
\frac{d z}{d x}=1-x^{2}, \text { or } d z=\left(1-x^{2}\right) d x
$$

After integration, we find

$$
z=x-\frac{x^{3}}{3}+C_{1}
$$

Hence,

$$
\frac{d y}{d x}=x-\frac{x^{3}}{3}+C_{1}, \text { or } \quad d y=x-\frac{x^{3}}{3}+C_{1} d x .
$$

Integrating this equation, we obtain the general solution

$$
y=\frac{x^{2}}{2}-\frac{x^{4}}{12}+C_{1} x+C_{2} .
$$

soln_description:
[Proof] For any positive integers $x$ and $y$, we use the symbol $x \sim y$ to denote that they have the same prime divisors.

Given $\left(b^{m}-1\right) \sim\left(b^{n}-1\right)$, therefore, any prime that divides $b^{\prime \prime \prime}-1$ also divides $b^{n}-1$, and thus also divides their greatest common divisor $\left(b^{m}-1, b^{n}-1\right)$. Hence,
$$
\left(b^{m}-1, b^{n}-1\right) \sim\left(b^{m}-1\right) \sim\left(b^{n}-1\right) .
$$

On the other hand, let $d=(m, n)$, then $\left(b^{\prime \prime \prime}-1, b^{\prime \prime}-1\right)=b^{d}-1$.
Let $a=b^{d}, k=\frac{m}{d}$, then $a^{k}-1 \sim a-1$.
First, we prove a special case of the original proposition, i.e., prove
$$
a^{k}-1 \sim a-1 \Rightarrow a+1 \text { is a power of } 2.
$$

To do this, we prove a lemma: Let $a, k$ be positive integers, and $p$ be an odd prime. If $p^{\alpha} \| a-1$ and $p^{\beta} \| k$, then $p^{\alpha+\beta} \| a^{k}-1$. Here $\alpha \geqslant 1, \beta \geqslant 0$.
We use mathematical induction on $\beta$.
If $\beta=0$, since $a^{k}-1=(a-1)\left(a^{k-1}+a^{k-2}+\cdots+a+1\right)$,
and $a \equiv 1(\bmod p)$ implies that for all $j \geqslant 0, a^{j} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$,
then $a^{k-1}+a^{k-2}+\cdots+a+1 \cong k(\bmod p)$.
Since $p^{\beta} \| k$ and $\beta=0$, then $p \nmid k$, so $p^{\alpha} \| a^{k}-1$.
When $\beta=0$, the lemma holds.
Now assume the conclusion holds for some $\beta$, and let $k=l p^{\beta+1}$, where $(l, p)=1$. By the induction hypothesis,
$$
p^{\alpha+\beta} \| a^{l p^{\beta}}-1 .
$$

Thus there exists some $m$ coprime with $p$ such that $a^{l p^{\beta}}=m p^{\alpha+\beta}+1$,
then $a^{k}-1=\left(a^{l p^{\beta}}\right)^{p}-1=\left(m p^{\alpha+\beta}+1\right)^{p}-1$
$$
=\left(m p^{\alpha+\beta}\right)^{p}+\cdots+C_{p}^{2}\left(m p^{\alpha+\beta}\right)^{2}+m p^{\alpha+\beta+1} .
$$
Since $p$ is odd and $p \mid C_{p}^{2}$, the exponent of $p$ in the second-to-last term of the above expression is $2 \alpha+2 \beta+1$, which is greater than the exponent of $p$ in the last term $\alpha+\beta+1$. Therefore, from the above expression, the highest power of $p$ in the factorization of $a^{k}-1$ is $\alpha+\beta+1$,
i.e.,
$$
p^{\alpha+\beta+1} \| a^{k}-1 \text {. }
$$

Thus, the lemma is proved.
Next, we prove: If $a>1$, and for some $k>1$, $a^{k}-1 \sim a-1$, then $a+1$ is a power of 2.

First, note that if $\delta$ is a divisor of $k$, then $a^{\delta}-1 \sim a-1$ follows from $a^{k}-1 \sim a-1$.

Indeed, any prime divisor of $a^{\delta}-1$ also divides $a^{k}-1$, and thus also divides $a-1$. Assume $k$ has an odd prime divisor $p$, and let $\delta=p^{\beta}$, where $p^{\beta} \| k$. Since
$$
a^{\delta}-1=(a-1)\left(a^{\delta-1}+a^{\delta-2}+\cdots+a+1\right),
$$

let $q$ be a prime divisor of $A=a^{\delta-1}+a^{\delta-2}+\cdots+a+1$, then $q$ divides $a^{\delta}-1$, and thus divides $a-1$.
This implies that for all $j=0,1,2, \cdots, a^{j} \equiv 1(\bmod q)$,
thus $A \equiv \delta \quad(\bmod q)$.
Since $q$ divides $\delta=p^{\beta}$, it follows that $q=p$, so $A$ is a power of $p$.
We have also shown that $p$ divides $a-1$.
Let $p^{\alpha} \| a-1$, then by the lemma, $p^{\alpha+\beta} \| a^{\delta}-1$.
Thus, from the factorization of $a^{\delta}-1$, the exponent of $p$ in the factorization of $A$ is
$(\alpha+\beta)-\alpha=\beta$. On the other hand, $p$ is the only prime divisor of $A$, so $A=p^{\beta}=\delta$, but this is impossible because $a>1$ implies $A>\delta$.

Thus, we have shown that $k$ is a power of 2, and since $k>1$, $k$ is even, so
$$
a-1 \sim a^{2}-1=(a-1)(a+1) .
$$

This implies that any prime divisor $q$ of $a+1$ is also a divisor of $a-1$, meaning $q$ divides $(a+1)-(a-1)=2$, so $q=2$, thus $a+1$ is a power of 2.
Returning to the case $a=b^{d}$.
If $d$ is even, since $b$ is odd, then $a+1=b^{d}+1 \equiv 2(\bmod 4)$.
Since $a+1$ is a power of 2, it follows that $a+1=2$, which contradicts the condition $a>1$.
Therefore, $d$ must be odd, so $b+1 \mid b^{d}+1$.
Since $b^{d}+1$ is a power of 2, $b+1$ is also a power of 2.
informal_statement:

Ôºà38th International Mathematical Olympiad Preliminary Question, 1997Ôºâ

soln_description:
Let $A_{1}=\{S$ where the numbers are divisible by 2 $\}, A_{2}=\{S$ where the numbers are divisible by 3 $\}, A_{3}=\{S$ where the numbers are divisible by 5 $\}, A_{4}=\{S$ where the numbers are divisible by 7 $\}$, and denote $A=A_{1} \cup A_{2} \cup A_{3} \cup A_{4}$. It is easy to see that $|A|=216$.
Since any 5 numbers chosen from $A$ must have at least two numbers in the same $A_{i}$, and these two numbers are not coprime, it follows that $n \geqslant 217$.
On the other hand, let $B_{1}=\{1$ and all prime numbers in $S\}, B_{2}=\left\{2^{2}, 3^{2}, 5^{2}, 7^{2}, 11^{2}, 13^{2}\right\}, B_{3}=\{2 \times$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
131,3 \times 89,5 \times 53,7 \times 37,11 \times 23,13 \times 19\}, B_{4}=\{2 \times 127,3 \times 83,5 \times 47,7 \times 31,11 \times 19, \\
13 \times 17\}, B_{5}=\{2 \times 113,3 \times 79,5 \times 43,7 \times 29,11 \times 17\}, B_{6}=\{2 \times 109,3 \times 73,5 \times 41,7 \times \\
23,11 \times 13\} .
\end{array}
$$

Denote $B=B_{1} \cup B_{2} \cup \cdots \cup B_{6}$, then $|B|=88$. Thus, $S / B$ contains 192 elements. If we choose 217 numbers from $S$, since $217-192=25$, there must be 25 elements in $B$. Therefore, there must be 5 numbers in the same $B_{i}$, and these numbers are pairwise coprime.
Hence, the minimum value of $n$ is 217.
informal_statement: Example 6 Let $S=\{1,2,3, \cdots, 280\}$. Find the smallest natural number $n$ such that every subset of $S$ with $n$ elements contains 5 pairwise coprime numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

    IsLeast {n | ‚àÄ T ‚äÜ S, T.card = n ‚Üí ‚àÉ V ‚äÜ T, V.card = 5 ‚àß ‚àÄ x ‚àà V, ‚àÄ y ‚àà V, x ‚â† y ‚Üí Nat.Coprime x y} 217 := by

. On has: $\forall n \in \mathbb{N},-1 \leq(-1)^{n} \leq 1$ thus $\forall n \in \mathbb{N}, \frac{n-1}{n+2} \leq$ $u_{n} \leq \frac{n+1}{n+2}$, hence, by the squeeze theorem, we deduce that the sequence $\left(u_{n}\right)$ tends to 1.

Theorem 4. Let $\left(u_{n}\right)$ and $\left(v_{n}\right)$ be two sequences of real numbers such that: $\forall n \in \mathbb{N}, u_{n} \leq v_{n}$.

1. If $\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} u_{n}=+\infty$ then $\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} v_{n}=+\infty$.
2. If $\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} v_{n}=-\infty$ then $\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} u_{n}=-\infty$.

The proof of this theorem is almost immediate, so it is left as an exercise.

III) Training exercises.

soln_description:
50. If the product $\left(a^{2}+1\right)\left(b^{1}+1\right)$ is divisible by $c^{2}+1$, then $c^{2}+1$ can be factored into a product of two factors $X Y$ such that $a^{2}+1$ is divisible by $X$, and $b^{2}+1$ is divisible by $Y$. (For this, it is sufficient, for example, to set $X=\left(a^{2}+1, c^{2}+1\right)$.) We will assume, without loss of generality, that $X \geqslant Y$, then $Y \leqslant c$.

Let $u$ be the remainder of the division of $a$ by $c^{2}+1$, and $v$ be the remainder of the division of $b$ by $Y$. Then $u \leqslant c^{2}, v<Y \leqslant c$, hence $u v<c^{3}$. It is easy to see that $u^{2}+1$ is divisible by $X$, but not by $c^{2}+1$, and $v^{2}+1$ is divisible by $Y$, but clearly not by $c^{2}+1$. Therefore, the product $\left(u^{2}+1\right)\left(v^{2}+1\right)$ is divisible by $X Y=c^{2}+1$. Thus, $u, v, c-$ is an interesting triplet.
informal_statement:
50. We will call a triplet of natural numbers $a, b, c$ interesting if $\left(a^{2}+1\right)\left(b^{2}+1\right)$ is divisible by $c^{2}+1$, but neither of the two factors is divisible by $c^{2}+1$.

Given an interesting triplet $a, b, c$. Prove that there exist natural numbers $u, v$, such that the triplet $u, v, c$ is interesting and $uv < c^{3}$.
formal_statement:

/- 50. We will call a triplet of natural numbers $a, b, c$ interesting if $\left(a^{2}+1\right)\left(b^{2}+1\right)$ is divisible by $c^{2}+1$, but neither of the two factors is divisible by $c^{2}+1$.

Given an interesting triplet $a, b, c$. Prove that there exist natural numbers $u, v$, such that the triplet $u, v, c$ is interesting and $uv < c^{3}$. -/
theorem number_theory_182855 (a b c : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : (a^2 + 1) * (b^2 + 1) % (c^2 + 1) = 0)
    (h‚ÇÅ : ¬¨((c^2 + 1) ‚à£ (a^2 + 1))) (h‚ÇÇ : ¬¨((c^2 + 1) ‚à£ (b^2 + 1))) :
    ‚àÉ u v, (u^2 + 1) * (v^2 + 1) % (c^2 + 1) = 0 ‚àß ¬¨((c^2 + 1) ‚à£ (u^2 + 1)) ‚àß
    ¬¨((c^2 + 1) ‚à£ (v^2 + 1)) ‚àß u * v < c^3 := by

soln_description:
118. Since $(a-1)^{2}(a+1) \geqslant 0$, we have $a^{3}+2 \geqslant a^{2}+a+1$. Similarly, $b^{3}+2 \geqslant b^{2}+b+1$, $c^{3}+2 \geqslant c^{2}+c+1$, so
$$\frac{1}{a^{2}+a+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+b+1}+\frac{1}{c^{2}+c+1} \geqslant \frac{1}{a^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{b^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{c^{3}+2}$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we get
$$\left(\frac{1}{a^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{b^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{c^{3}+2}\right)\left[\left(a^{3}+2\right)+\left(b^{3}+2\right)+\left(c^{3}+2\right)\right] \geqslant 9$$

Since $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}=3$, we have $\frac{1}{a^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{b^{3}+2}+\frac{1}{c^{3}+2} \geqslant 1$.
informal_statement: 118. Let positive real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfy $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}=3$, prove: $\frac{1}{a^{2}+a+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+b+1}+$ $\frac{1}{c^{2}+c+1} \geqslant 1$. (2010 Chen Province Cup Mathematical Olympiad Problem)
informal_proof:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers such that $a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = 3$. We want to prove that $\frac{1}{a^2 + a + 1} + \frac{1}{b^2 + b + 1} + \frac{1}{c^2 + c + 1} \ge 1$.

Our strategy is to first establish a lower bound for each term in the sum. We will show that for any positive real number $x$, the following inequality holds:
$$ \frac{1}{x^2 + x + 1} \ge \frac{4 - x^3}{9} $$
Since $x > 0$, the denominator $x^2 + x + 1$ is strictly positive. Thus, we can multiply both sides by $9(x^2 + x + 1)$ without changing the direction of the inequality, yielding the equivalent inequality:
$$ 9 \ge (4 - x^3)(x^2 + x + 1) $$
Expanding the right-hand side, we get:
$$ 9 \ge 4x^2 + 4x + 4 - x^5 - x^4 - x^3 $$
Rearranging the terms to one side, we need to prove:
$$ x^5 + x^4 + x^3 - 4x^2 - 4x + 5 \ge 0 $$
Let $P(x) = x^5 + x^4 + x^3 - 4x^2 - 4x + 5$. We can factor this polynomial as:
$$ P(x) = (x - 1)^2 (x^3 + 3x^2 + 6x + 5) $$
For any real number $x$, the term $(x - 1)^2$ is always non-negative. Since we are given that $x$ is a positive real number, each term in the second factor, $x^3 + 3x^2 + 6x + 5$, is positive. Therefore, their sum is also positive. The product of a non-negative number and a positive number is non-negative, so $P(x) \ge 0$ for all $x > 0$. This confirms our intermediate inequality.

Applying this result for $a$, $b$, and $c$ respectively, we have:
\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{a^2 + a + 1} &\ge \frac{4 - a^3}{9} \\
\frac{1}{b^2 + b + 1} &\ge \frac{4 - b^3}{9} \\
\frac{1}{c^2 + c + 1} &\ge \frac{4 - c^3}{9}
\end{align*}
Summing these three inequalities, we obtain:
$$ \frac{1}{a^2 + a + 1} + \frac{1}{b^2 + b + 1} + \frac{1}{c^2 + c + 1} \ge \frac{4 - a^3}{9} + \frac{4 - b^3}{9} + \frac{4 - c^3}{9} $$
Now, let's simplify the right-hand side of this inequality:
$$ \frac{4 - a^3}{9} + \frac{4 - b^3}{9} + \frac{4 - c^3}{9} = \frac{(4 - a^3) + (4 - b^3) + (4 - c^3)}{9} = \frac{12 - (a^3 + b^3 + c^3)}{9} $$
Using the given condition $a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = 3$, this expression becomes:
$$ \frac{12 - 3}{9} = \frac{9}{9} = 1 $$
Thus, we have shown that
$$ \frac{1}{a^2 + a + 1} + \frac{1}{b^2 + b + 1} + \frac{1}{c^2 + c + 1} \ge 1 $$
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 118. Let positive real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfy $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}=3$, prove: $\frac{1}{a^{2}+a+1}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+b+1}+$ $\frac{1}{c^{2}+c+1} \geqslant 1$. (2010 Chen Province Cup Mathematical Olympiad Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_601836 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = 3) :
    1 ‚â§ 1 / (a^2 + a + 1) + 1 / (b^2 + b + 1) + 1 / (c^2 + c + 1) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_601836 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = 3) :
    1 ‚â§ 1 / (a^2 + a + 1) + 1 / (b^2 + b + 1) + 1 / (c^2 + c + 1) := by
  have h1 : 1 / (a^2 + a + 1) ‚â• (4 - a^3) / 9 := by
    apply (le_div_iff‚ÇÄ (by positivity)).mpr
    suffices (4 - a^3) * (a^2 + a + 1) ‚â§ 9 by linarith
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (a - 1), sq_nonneg (a + 1), sq_nonneg (a^3 - 1), sq_nonneg (a^3 + a - 2), sq_nonneg (a^2 + a - 2)]
  have h2 : 1 / (b^2 + b + 1) ‚â• (4 - b^3) / 9 := by
    apply (le_div_iff‚ÇÄ (by positivity)).mpr
    suffices (4 - b^3) * (b^2 + b + 1) ‚â§ 9 by linarith
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (b^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (b - 1), sq_nonneg (b + 1), sq_nonneg (b^3 - 1), sq_nonneg (b^3 + b - 2), sq_nonneg (b^2 + b - 2)]
  have h3 : 1 / (c^2 + c + 1) ‚â• (4 - c^3) / 9 := by
    apply (le_div_iff‚ÇÄ (by positivity)).mpr
    suffices (4 - c^3) * (c^2 + c + 1) ‚â§ 9 by linarith
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (c^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (c - 1), sq_nonneg (c + 1), sq_nonneg (c^3 - 1), sq_nonneg (c^3 + c - 2), sq_nonneg (c^2 + c - 2)]
  have h4 : 1 / (a^2 + a + 1) + 1 / (b^2 + b + 1) + 1 / (c^2 + c + 1) ‚â• (4 - a^3) / 9 + (4 - b^3) / 9 + (4 - c^3) / 9 := by linarith [h1, h2, h3]
  have h5 : (4 - a^3) / 9 + (4 - b^3) / 9 + (4 - c^3) / 9 = 1 := by
    linarith [h]
  linarith [h4, h5]

soln_description:
Instruction. $7^{2(n+1)}=49^{n+1}=(41+8)^{n+1} ; 2^{3 n}=8^{n} ;$

$$
5 \cdot 7^{2(n+1)}+2^{3 n}=5 \cdot(41+8)^{n+1}+8^{n}=
$$

$=5 \cdot 41^{n+1}+(n+1) \cdot 5 \cdot 8 \cdot 41^{n}+\ldots+(n+1) \cdot 5 \cdot 41 \cdot 8^{n}+$ $+5 \cdot 8^{n+1}+8^{n}$ is divisible by 41, since

$$
5 \cdot 8^{n+1}+8^{n}=8^{n} \cdot 41
$$

Note. In problems $130-132$, it is necessary to apply artificial transformation - adding and subtracting the same quantity from the given expression.
informal_statement: 129. Prove that $5 \cdot 7^{2(n+1)} + 2^{3n}$ for natural $n$ is divisible by 41.
informal_proof:
We will prove by mathematical induction that for all natural numbers $n$, the expression $5 \cdot 7^{2n+2} + 2^{3n}$ is divisible by $41$.

Let $P(n)$ be the proposition $41 \mid (5 \cdot 7^{2n+2} + 2^{3n})$.

**Base Case:** For $n=0$, we must show that $P(0)$ is true.
The expression is:
$5 \cdot 7^{2(0)+2} + 2^{3(0)} = 5 \cdot 7^2 + 2^0 = 5 \cdot 49 + 1 = 245 + 1 = 246$.
Since $246 = 6 \cdot 41$, the expression is divisible by $41$. Thus, the base case $P(0)$ holds.

**Inductive Step:** Assume that $P(k)$ is true for some arbitrary natural number $k \geq 0$. That is, assume:
$41 \mid (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2} + 2^{3k})$. This is our inductive hypothesis.

We must show that $P(k+1)$ is also true, i.e., that $41 \mid (5 \cdot 7^{2(k+1)+2} + 2^{3(k+1)})$.

Let's consider the expression for $n=k+1$:
$$ 5 \cdot 7^{2(k+1)+2} + 2^{3(k+1)} $$
First, we simplify the exponents:
$$ = 5 \cdot 7^{2k+4} + 2^{3k+3} $$
Next, we manipulate the expression to relate it to the expression in our inductive hypothesis:
$$ = 5 \cdot 7^2 \cdot 7^{2k+2} + 2^3 \cdot 2^{3k} $$
$$ = 49 \cdot (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2}) + 8 \cdot 2^{3k} $$
Our goal is to show that this expression is divisible by $41$. We can rewrite $49$ as $41+8$:
$$ = (41 + 8) \cdot (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2}) + 8 \cdot 2^{3k} $$
Distributing the terms, we get:
$$ = 41 \cdot (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2}) + 8 \cdot (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2}) + 8 \cdot 2^{3k} $$
Now, we can factor out $8$ from the last two terms:
$$ = 41 \cdot (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2}) + 8 \cdot (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2} + 2^{3k}) $$
Let's analyze this sum. The first term, $41 \cdot (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2})$, is clearly a multiple of $41$.
The second term, $8 \cdot (5 \cdot 7^{2k+2} + 2^{3k})$, is also a multiple of $41$ because, by our inductive hypothesis, the expression $(5 \cdot 7^{2k+2} + 2^{3k})$ is divisible by $41$.

Since both terms in the sum are divisible by $41$, their sum must also be divisible by $41$.
Thus, we have shown that if $P(k)$ is true, then $P(k+1)$ is true.

By the principle of mathematical induction, the statement $P(n)$ holds for all natural numbers $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 129. Prove that $5 \cdot 7^{2(n+1)} + 2^{3n}$ for natural $n$ is divisible by 41. -/
theorem number_theory_276062 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    41 ‚à£ 5 * 7^(2*n + 2) + 2^(3*n) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_276062 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    41 ‚à£ 5 * 7^(2*n + 2) + 2^(3*n) := by
  have h1 : ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, 41 ‚à£ 5 * 7 ^ (2 * n + 2) + 2 ^ (3 * n) := by
    intro n
    induction n with
    | zero =>
      norm_num
    | succ n ih =>
      have h2 : 5 * 7 ^ (2 * (n + 1) + 2) + 2 ^ (3 * (n + 1)) =
          49 * (5 * 7 ^ (2 * n + 2)) + 8 * (2 ^ (3 * n)) := by
        ring_nf
      rw [h2]
      omega
  exact h1 n

Since $f(x)$ is a polynomial, we know that $f(x+1)$ and $f(x-1)$ have the same degree as $f(x)$. Therefore, $f(x)$ is a quadratic polynomial (let's assume $f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c$). Then,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(x+1) + f(x-1) \\
= 2ax^2 + 2bx + 2(a + c) = 2x^2 - 4x.
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $a = 1, b = -2, c = -1$.
Hence, $f(x) = x^2 - 2x - 1 = (x-1)^2 - 2 \geqslant -2$.

soln_description:
Obviously, $a, b, c$ are pairwise divisors, because, for example, every common divisor of $a$ and $b$ is also a divisor of 1 because of $a \mid b c-1$ . Since $b c-1$ is divisible by $a$, $a b+b c+c a-1$ must also be divisible by $a$, and for reasons of symmetry the same applies to $b$ and $c$. Because of the divisor strangeness of $a, b$ and $c$, we therefore obtain

$$
a b c \mid a b+b c+c a-1
$$

In particular, the left-hand side is not greater than the right-hand side, i.e. after division by $a b c$

$$
\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}-\frac{1}{a b c} \geq 1
$$

We can now assume $a \leq b \leq c$ and distinguish three cases:

(i) For $a \geq 3$ the left-hand side is less than 1, contradiction.

(ii) Let $a=2$. For $b \geq 4$ the left-hand side is less than 1, therefore $b=2.3$. Only $b=3$ leads to the solution $c=5$.

(iii) For $a=1$ we obtain $c \mid b-1$ from the original conditions. Because of $c \geq b$ it follows that $b=1$.

It is easy to see that in the cases $(a, b, c)=(2,3,5)$ and $a=b=1$ the conditions are fulfilled, so the triples $(a, b, c)$ we are looking for are the permutations of

$$
(2,3,5) \quad \text { and } \quad(1,1, n), \quad n \geq 1
$$
informal_statement:
a|b c-1, \quad b| c a-1, \quad c \mid a b-1
$$

## 1st solution

Solution. Let's check the necessary condition for convergence (Theorem 1). We have \(\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} u_{n}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n-1}{3 n+20}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n\left(1-\frac{1}{20}\right)}{n\left(3+\frac{20}{n}\right)}=\frac{1}{3} \neq 0\).

The series diverges. Since its terms are positive, the series diverges to \(+\infty\).
Answer. The series diverges.

Example 4. Investigate the convergence of the series \(\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \cos \pi n\).

Solution. We have \(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \cos \pi n=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}(-1)^{n} \neq 0\) (the limit does not exist). According to Theorem 1, the series diverges. Additionally, we have: \(S_{1}=\cos \pi=-1, \quad S_{2}=\cos \pi+\cos 2 \pi=-1+1=0\), \(S_{3}=\cos \pi+\cos 2 \pi+\cos 3 \pi=-1+1-1=-1, \ldots, \lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} S_{n}\) does not exist at all.

Answer. The series diverges.

informal_statement:
128. Prove that two consecutive numbers are coprime.

 untranslated text remains the same as requested. However, the task was to translate the text, which I have done. Let me know if you need anything else!
informal_proof:
Let \(n\) be an arbitrary integer. To prove that \(n\) and \(n+1\) are coprime, we must show that there exist integers \(x\) and \(y\) such that \(n \cdot x + (n+1) \cdot y = 1\). This is known as B√©zout's identity.

We can choose specific integers for \(x\) and \(y\). Let \(x = -1\) and \(y = 1\). We now verify if this choice satisfies the identity. Substituting these values into the equation, we get:
\[ n \cdot (-1) + (n+1) \cdot 1 \]
By distributing the terms, the expression becomes:
\[ -n + (n+1) \]
Simplifying the expression, we have:
\[ (-n + n) + 1 = 0 + 1 = 1 \]
Since we have found integers \(x = -1\) and \(y = 1\) such that \(n \cdot x + (n+1) \cdot y = 1\), we conclude that \(n\) and \(n+1\) are coprime.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

 untranslated text remains the same as requested. However, the task was to translate the text, which I have done. Let me know if you need anything else! -/

  show IsCoprime n (n + 1)
  use -1, 1
  ring_nf
  <;> omega

informal_statement: Simplify $\frac{2019}{66561}$.
informal_proof:
To show that $\frac{2019}{66561} = \frac{673}{22187}$, we will simplify the fraction on the left-hand side by finding a common divisor for the numerator and the denominator.

First, consider the numerator, 2019. The sum of its digits is $2 + 0 + 1 + 9 = 12$. Since 12 is divisible by 3, the number 2019 is also divisible by 3. Performing the division, we find:
$$2019 = 3 \times 673$$

Next, consider the denominator, 66561. The sum of its digits is $6 + 6 + 5 + 6 + 1 = 24$. Since 24 is divisible by 3, the number 66561 is also divisible by 3. Performing the division, we find:
$$66561 = 3 \times 22187$$

Now, we can substitute these factorizations back into the original fraction:
$$ \frac{2019}{66561} = \frac{3 \times 673}{3 \times 22187} $$

Since 3 is a common factor in both the numerator and the denominator, we can cancel it out:
$$ \frac{3 \times 673}{3 \times 22187} = \frac{673}{22187} $$

This confirms that the simplified form of $\frac{2019}{66561}$ is indeed $\frac{673}{22187}$. Therefore, the equality holds.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Simplify $\frac{2019}{66561}$. -/
theorem number_theory_3268 : (2019 : ‚Ñù) / 66561 = 673 / 22187 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_3268 : (2019 : ‚Ñù) / 66561 = 673 / 22187 := by 
  norm_num

soln_description:
1. Let \( a, b, c, \) and \( d \) be the roots of the quartic equation \( x^4 - 18x^3 + kx^2 + 200x - 1984 = 0 \).

2. By Vieta's formulas, we have the following relationships:
   \[
   a + b + c + d = 18
   \]
   \[
   ab + ac + ad + bc + bd + cd = k
   \]
   \[
   abc + abd + acd + bcd = -200
   \]
   \[
   abcd = -1984
   \]

3. We are given that the product of two of the roots is \(-32\). Without loss of generality, let \( ab = -32 \).

4. Using the product of all roots:
   \[
   abcd = -1984
   \]
   \[
   \frac{abcd}{ab} = \frac{-1984}{-32} = 62
   \]
   Thus, \( cd = 62 \).

5. We need to find \( k \). Using Vieta's formula for the sum of the products of the roots taken two at a time:
   \[
   ab + ac + ad + bc + bd + cd = k
   \]
   Substituting \( ab = -32 \) and \( cd = 62 \):
   \[
   k = -32 + ac + ad + bc + bd + 62
   \]
   \[
   k = 30 + ac + ad + bc + bd
   \]

6. We can factor \( ac + ad + bc + bd \) as \( (a + b)(c + d) \):
   \[
   ac + ad + bc + bd = (a + b)(c + d)
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   k = 30 + (a + b)(c + d)
   \]

7. We know from Vieta's formulas that:
   \[
   a + b + c + d = 18
   \]
   Let \( a + b = p \) and \( c + d = q \). Then:
   \[
   p + q = 18
   \]

8. We also know:
   \[
   ab = -32 \quad \text{and} \quad cd = 62
   \]

9. Using the relationship for the sum of the products of the roots taken three at a time:
   \[
   abc + abd + acd + bcd = ab(c + d) + cd(a + b) = -200
   \]
   Substituting \( ab = -32 \), \( cd = 62 \), and \( a + b = p \), \( c + d = q \):
   \[
   -32q + 62p = -200
   \]

10. Substituting \( q = 18 - p \):
    \[
    -32(18 - p) + 62p = -200
    \]
    \[
    -576 + 32p + 62p = -200
    \]
    \[
    94p = 376
    \]
    \[
    p = 4
    \]
    Therefore:
    \[
    q = 18 - 4 = 14
    \]

11. Substituting \( p = 4 \) and \( q = 14 \) back into the equation for \( k \):
    \[
    k = 30 + (a + b)(c + d)
    \]
    \[
    k = 30 + 4 \cdot 14
    \]
    \[
    k = 30 + 56
    \]
    \[
    k = 86
    \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{86} \).
informal_statement: The product of two of the four roots of the quartic equation $x^4 - 18x^3 + kx^2+200x-1984=0$ is $-32$. Determine the value of $k$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The product of two of the four roots of the quartic equation $x^4 - 18x^3 + kx^2+200x-1984=0$ is $-32$. Determine the value of $k$. -/
theorem algebra_45143 (k : ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÉ a b, a ‚â† b ‚àß a^4 - 18*a^3 + k*a^2 + 200*a - 1984 = 0 ‚àß b^4 - 18*b^3 + k*b^2 + 200*b - 1984 = 0 ‚àß a*b = -32) :
    k = 86 := by

soln_description:
$-1.1341$.
It is known that the numbers $a$ and $b$ are powers of 2 with non-negative integer exponents, i.e., $a=2^{k}, b=2^{2011-k}$. Therefore, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\Delta=a^{2}-4 b \geqslant 0 \\
\Rightarrow 2 k \geqslant 2013-k \Rightarrow k \geqslant \frac{2013}{3}=671 .
\end{array}
$$

But $k \leqslant 2011$, so $k$ can take
$$
2011-671+1=1341
$$

different integer values.
Each $k$ corresponds exactly to one of the required quadratic trinomials, hence there are 1341 such quadratic trinomials.
informal_statement:
1. The quadratic trinomial
$$
x^{2}+a x+b(a „ÄÅ b \in \mathbf{N})
$$

has real roots, and $a b=2^{2011}$. Then the number of such quadratic trinomials is $\qquad$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. The quadratic trinomial
$$
x^{2}+a x+b(a „ÄÅ b \in \mathbf{N})
$$

has real roots, and $a b=2^{2011}$. Then the number of such quadratic trinomials is $\qquad$. -/
theorem algebra_324183 (a b : ‚Ñï) (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : a * b = 2 ^ 2011)
    (hroots : ‚àÉ x : ‚Ñù, x ^ 2 + a * x + b = 0) :
    a = 1 ‚àß b = 2 ^ 2011 ‚à® a = 2 ^ 2011 ‚àß b = 1 := by

informal_statement:
Let $a_{1}=1, a_{2}=2$,
$$
a_{n}=4 a_{n-1}+a_{n-2}(n=3,4, \cdots) \text {. }
$$

If $p$ is an odd prime and $p \mid a_{n}$, prove: when $n$ is even, the remainder of $p$ modulo 10 is $1, 9$; when $n$ is odd, the remainder of $p$ modulo 20 is $1, 3, 7, 9$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a_{1}=1, a_{2}=2$,
$$
a_{n}=4 a_{n-1}+a_{n-2}(n=3,4, \cdots) \text {. }
$$

If $p$ is an odd prime and $p \mid a_{n}$, prove: when $n$ is even, the remainder of $p$ modulo 10 is $1, 9$; when $n$ is odd, the remainder of $p$ modulo 20 is $1, 3, 7, 9$. -/
theorem number_theory_230402 {a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï}
    (ha1 : a 1 = 1) (ha2 : a 2 = 2)
    (han : ‚àÄ n ‚â• 3, a n = 4 * a (n - 1) + a (n - 2)) :
    ‚àÄ p n, Odd p ‚Üí Prime p ‚Üí p ‚à£ a n ‚Üí (Even n ‚Üí p % 10 = 1 ‚à® p % 10 = 9) ‚àß
    (Odd n ‚Üí p % 20 = 1 ‚à® p % 20 = 3 ‚à® p % 20 = 7 ‚à® p % 20 = 9) := by

soln_description:
Answer: 182

Solution: Note that $a+2 b+c+2 d-a b-b c-c d-d a=(a+c)+2(b+d)-(a+$ $c)(b+d)$. Let $x=a+c, y=b+d$, then we will find the maximum value of the expression $x+2 y-x y=(y-1)(2-x)+2$, where $-14 \leqslant y-1 \leqslant 12$ and $-11 \leqslant 2-x \leqslant 15$. Therefore, $(y-1)(2-x)+2 \leqslant 12 \cdot 15+2=182$. The maximum value of the expression is achieved when $a=c=-6.5, b=d=6.5$.
informal_statement: 4. (7 points) The numbers $a, b, c, d$ belong to the interval $[-6.5,6.5]$. Find the maximum value of the expression $a+2 b+c+2 d-a b-b c-c d-d a$.
informal_proof:
To prove that 182 is the maximum value of the expression for `a, b, c, d` in the interval `[-6.5, 6.5]`, we must show two things: first, that the value 182 can be achieved, and second, that the expression is never greater than 182.

**1. Attainability of the maximum value**

We show that 182 is a possible value of the expression. Consider the specific values:
`a = -6.5`
`b = 6.5`
`c = -6.5`
`d = 6.5`

These values all lie within the required interval `[-6.5, 6.5]`. Substituting them into the expression `a + 2b + c + 2d - ab - bc - cd - da`:

`(-6.5) + 2(6.5) + (-6.5) + 2(6.5) - (-6.5)(6.5) - (6.5)(-6.5) - (-6.5)(6.5) - (6.5)(-6.5)`
`= -6.5 + 13 - 6.5 + 13 - (-42.25) - (-42.25) - (-42.25) - (-42.25)`
`= -13 + 26 + 4 * 42.25`
`= 13 + 169`
`= 182`

Thus, the value 182 is attained for a valid choice of `a, b, c, d`.

**2. Proof of the upper bound**

Let `a, b, c, d` be any real numbers in the interval `[-6.5, 6.5]`. Let the given expression be `E`. We can rearrange `E` by grouping terms:
`E = (a+c) + 2(b+d) - (ab + bc + cd + da)`

The term `ab + bc + cd + da` can be factored as `(a+c)(b+d)`. So the expression becomes:
`E = (a+c) + 2(b+d) - (a+c)(b+d)`

To simplify, let `X = a+c` and `Y = b+d`. The expression is now `E = X + 2Y - XY`. We can further rewrite this expression to make its properties clearer:
`E = 2 - 2 + X + 2Y - XY`
`E = 2 - (2 - X - 2Y + XY)`
`E = 2 - (2 - X)(1 - Y)`
`E = 2 + (2 - X)(Y - 1)`

Now, we determine the range of possible values for `X` and `Y`. Since `a, c ‚àà [-6.5, 6.5]`, their sum `X = a+c` must be in the interval `[-6.5 + (-6.5), 6.5 + 6.5]`, which is `[-13, 13]`. Similarly, since `b, d ‚àà [-6.5, 6.5]`, their sum `Y = b+d` must be in the interval `[-13, 13]`.

Using these ranges for `X` and `Y`, we can find the range for the factors in our expression for `E`:
-   Since `-13 ‚â§ X ‚â§ 13`, we have `-13 ‚â§ -X ‚â§ 13`, and so `2 - 13 ‚â§ 2 - X ‚â§ 2 + 13`, which means `-11 ‚â§ 2 - X ‚â§ 15`.
-   Since `-13 ‚â§ Y ‚â§ 13`, we have `-13 - 1 ‚â§ Y - 1 ‚â§ 13 - 1`, which means `-14 ‚â§ Y - 1 ‚â§ 12`.

To maximize `E = 2 + (2-X)(Y-1)`, we need to maximize the product `(2-X)(Y-1)`. The product of two numbers from the intervals `[-11, 15]` and `[-14, 12]` is maximized by taking the product of the largest positive numbers from each interval.
The maximum value of `(2-X)` is 15.
The maximum value of `(Y-1)` is 12.
Therefore, the maximum value of the product `(2-X)(Y-1)` is `15 * 12 = 180`.

Substituting this maximum value back into the expression for `E`, we find the maximum possible value for `E`:
`E_max = 2 + 180 = 182`

This shows that for any `a, b, c, d` in `[-6.5, 6.5]`, the expression is less than or equal to 182.

Since 182 is an attainable value and also an upper bound for all possible values of the expression, it is the maximum value.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. (7 points) The numbers $a, b, c, d$ belong to the interval $[-6.5,6.5]$. Find the maximum value of the expression $a+2 b+c+2 d-a b-b c-c d-d a$. -/
theorem algebra_197335 :
    IsGreatest {x | ‚àÉ a b c d : ‚Ñù, x = a + 2 * b + c + 2 * d - a * b - b * c - c * d - d * a ‚àß
      a ‚àà Set.Icc (-6.5) 6.5 ‚àß b ‚àà Set.Icc (-6.5) 6.5 ‚àß c ‚àà Set.Icc (-6.5) 6.5 ‚àß d ‚àà Set.Icc (-6.5) 6.5} 182 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_197335 :
    IsGreatest {x | ‚àÉ a b c d : ‚Ñù, x = a + 2 * b + c + 2 * d - a * b - b * c - c * d - d * a ‚àß
      a ‚àà Set.Icc (-6.5) 6.5 ‚àß b ‚àà Set.Icc (-6.5) 6.5 ‚àß c ‚àà Set.Icc (-6.5) 6.5 ‚àß d ‚àà Set.Icc (-6.5) 6.5} 182 := by 
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that 182 is attained, so it is in the set
    use -6.5, 6.5, -6.5, 6.5
    norm_num [Set.mem_Icc]
  ¬∑ -- Show that 182 is the greatest
    intro x hx
    rcases hx with ‚ü®a, b, c, d, heq, ha, hb, hc, hd‚ü©
    rw [Set.mem_Icc] at ha hb hc hd
    -- Unpack the bounds
    rcases ha with ‚ü®ha1, ha2‚ü©
    rcases hb with ‚ü®hb1, hb2‚ü©
    rcases hc with ‚ü®hc1, hc2‚ü©
    rcases hd with ‚ü®hd1, hd2‚ü©
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a + 6.5), sq_nonneg (b - 6.5), sq_nonneg (c + 6.5), sq_nonneg (d - 6.5), sq_nonneg (a + c + 13), sq_nonneg (b + d - 13)]

soln_description:
1. Let \( A(k) = a_0 + a_1k + a_2k^2 + a_3k^3 \) be the area of the section at \( z = k \). The volume \( V \) of the solid can be found by integrating the area function over the height of the solid:
   \[
   V = \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} A(k) \, dk = \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} (a_0 + a_1k + a_2k^2 + a_3k^3) \, dk
   \]

2. Evaluate the integral term by term:
   \[
   \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} a_0 \, dk = a_0 \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} 1 \, dk = a_0 \left[ k \right]_{-h/2}^{h/2} = a_0 \left( \frac{h}{2} - \left( -\frac{h}{2} \right) \right) = a_0 h
   \]

   \[
   \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} a_1k \, dk = a_1 \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} k \, dk = a_1 \left[ \frac{k^2}{2} \right]_{-h/2}^{h/2} = a_1 \left( \frac{(h/2)^2}{2} - \frac{(-h/2)^2}{2} \right) = 0
   \]

   \[
   \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} a_2k^2 \, dk = a_2 \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} k^2 \, dk = a_2 \left[ \frac{k^3}{3} \right]_{-h/2}^{h/2} = a_2 \left( \frac{(h/2)^3}{3} - \frac{(-h/2)^3}{3} \right) = a_2 \left( \frac{h^3}{24} - \left( -\frac{h^3}{24} \right) \right) = \frac{a_2 h^3}{12}
   \]

   \[
   \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} a_3k^3 \, dk = a_3 \int_{-h/2}^{h/2} k^3 \, dk = a_3 \left[ \frac{k^4}{4} \right]_{-h/2}^{h/2} = a_3 \left( \frac{(h/2)^4}{4} - \frac{(-h/2)^4}{4} \right) = 0
   \]

3. Summing these results, we get:
   \[
   V = a_0 h + \frac{a_2 h^3}{12}
   \]

4. Now, we need to show that this volume can also be expressed as \( \frac{h(B + 4M + T)}{6} \), where \( B = A(-h/2) \), \( M = A(0) \), and \( T = A(h/2) \).

5. Calculate \( A(-h/2) \), \( A(0) \), and \( A(h/2) \):
   \[
   A(-h/2) = a_0 - a_1 \frac{h}{2} + a_2 \left( \frac{h}{2} \right)^2 - a_3 \left( \frac{h}{2} \right)^3 = a_0 - a_1 \frac{h}{2} + a_2 \frac{h^2}{4} - a_3 \frac{h^3}{8}
   \]

   \[
   A(0) = a_0
   \]

   \[
   A(h/2) = a_0 + a_1 \frac{h}{2} + a_2 \left( \frac{h}{2} \right)^2 + a_3 \left( \frac{h}{2} \right)^3 = a_0 + a_1 \frac{h}{2} + a_2 \frac{h^2}{4} + a_3 \frac{h^3}{8}
   \]

6. Substitute these into the expression \( \frac{h(B + 4M + T)}{6} \):
   \[
   \frac{h(A(-h/2) + 4A(0) + A(h/2))}{6} = \frac{h \left( (a_0 - a_1 \frac{h}{2} + a_2 \frac{h^2}{4} - a_3 \frac{h^3}{8}) + 4a_0 + (a_0 + a_1 \frac{h}{2} + a_2 \frac{h^2}{4} + a_3 \frac{h^3}{8}) \right)}{6}
   \]

7. Simplify the expression inside the parentheses:
   \[
   = \frac{h \left( 6a_0 + 2a_2 \frac{h^2}{4} \right)}{6} = \frac{h \left( 6a_0 + \frac{a_2 h^2}{2} \right)}{6} = a_0 h + \frac{a_2 h^3}{12}
   \]

8. This matches the volume expression we derived earlier, confirming that:
   \[
   V = \frac{h(B + 4M + T)}{6}
   \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{ \frac{h(B + 4M + T)}{6} } \)
informal_statement: A solid in Euclidean $3$-space extends from $z = \frac{-h}{2}$ to $z = \frac{+h}{2}$ and the area of the section $z = k$ is a polynomial in $k$ of degree at most $3$. Show that the volume of the solid is $\frac{h(B + 4M + T)}{6},$ where $B$ is the area of the bottom $(z = \frac{-h}{2})$, $M$ is the area of the middle section $(z = 0),$ and $T$ is the area of the top $(z = \frac{h}{2})$. Derive the formulae for the volumes of a cone and a sphere.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- A solid in Euclidean $3$-space extends from $z = \frac{-h}{2}$ to $z = \frac{+h}{2}$ and the area of the section $z = k$ is a polynomial in $k$ of degree at most $3$. Show that the volume of the solid is $\frac{h(B + 4M + T)}{6},$ where $B$ is the area of the bottom $(z = \frac{-h}{2})$, $M$ is the area of the middle section $(z = 0),$ and $T$ is the area of the top $(z = \frac{h}{2})$. Derive the formulae for the volumes of a cone and a sphere. -/
theorem calculus_44135 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : ‚àÉ p : Polynomial ‚Ñù, p.degree ‚â§ 3 ‚àß ‚àÄ k, f k = p.eval k)
  (h : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : h > 0) (B M T : ‚Ñù)
  (hB : B = f (-h / 2)) (hM : M = f 0) (hT : T = f (h / 2)) :
  ‚à´ k in (-h / 2)..(h / 2), f k = (h * (B + 4 * M + T)) / 6 :=

soln_description:
Solution. From $\frac{a y-b x}{c}=\frac{c x-a z}{b}$ we have $y=\frac{c^{2} x-a c z+b^{2} x}{a b}$, and from $\frac{c x-a z}{b}=\frac{b z-c y}{a}$ we have $y=\frac{b^{2} z-a c x+a^{2} z}{b c}$. Then from $\frac{c^{2} x-a c z+b^{2} x}{a b}=\frac{b^{2} z-a c x+a^{2} z}{b c}$ we get $c x\left(c^{2}+b^{2}+a^{2}\right)=a z\left(c^{2}+b^{2}+a^{2}\right)$.

Since $a, b, c \neq 0$, we have $c^{2}+b^{2}+a^{2} \neq 0$. Therefore $c x=a z$, i.e., $\frac{x}{a}=\frac{z}{c}$. From $c x=a z$ it follows that $\frac{a y-b x}{c}=\frac{c x-a z}{b}=0$, i.e., $a y-b x=0$. Thus $a y=b x$, i.e., $\frac{x}{a}=\frac{y}{b}$.
informal_statement: 1. If for non-zero numbers $a, b, c$ it holds that $\frac{a y - b x}{c} = \frac{c x - a z}{b} = \frac{b z - c y}{a}$, then $\frac{x}{a} = \frac{y}{b} = \frac{z}{c}$. Prove.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. If for non-zero numbers $a, b, c$ it holds that $\frac{a y - b x}{c} = \frac{c x - a z}{b} = \frac{b z - c y}{a}$, then $\frac{x}{a} = \frac{y}{b} = \frac{z}{c}$. Prove. -/
theorem algebra_240521 {x y z a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (hb : b ‚â† 0) (hc : c ‚â† 0)
    (h : (a * y - b * x) / c = (c * x - a * z) / b) (h' : (c * x - a * z) / b = (b * z - c * y) / a) :
    x / a = y / b ‚àß y / b = z / c := by

informal_statement: Find all triples $(a, b, c)$ of integers greater than 1 such that $(a+1)^b = a^c + 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all triples $(a, b, c)$ of integers greater than 1 such that $(a+1)^b = a^c + 1$. -/
theorem number_theory_3158 (a b c : ‚Ñï) (ha : 1 < a) (hb : 1 < b) (hc : 1 < c) : (a + 1)^b = a^c + 1 ‚Üî (a, b, c) = (2, 2, 3) := by

soln_description: A9. When Ko Cene runs $1000 \mathrm{~m}$, Tonet is $10 \mathrm{~m}$ short of the finish line. Milan is somewhat slower than Tonet, as he gradually falls behind from the start: when Tonet runs $1000 \mathrm{~m}$, Milan is $20 \mathrm{~m}$ behind him. Therefore, when Tonet runs $990 \mathrm{~m}$, Milan is $\frac{990.20}{1000}=\frac{99}{5}=19.8 \mathrm{~m}$ behind Tonet. Cene thus outpaces Milan by $10+19.8=29.8 \mathrm{~m}$.
informal_statement:
A9. When Cene runs $1000 \mathrm{~m}$, Tone is $10 \mathrm{~m}$ behind him. When Tone runs $1000 \mathrm{~m}$, Milan is $20 \mathrm{~m}$ behind him. By how many meters will Cene outpace Milan in a $1000 \mathrm{~m}$ race?
(A) 30.1
(B) 30
(C) 10
(D) 29.8
(E) It is impossible to determine.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A9. When Cene runs $1000 \mathrm{~m}$, Tone is $10 \mathrm{~m}$ behind him. When Tone runs $1000 \mathrm{~m}$, Milan is $20 \mathrm{~m}$ behind him. By how many meters will Cene outpace Milan in a $1000 \mathrm{~m}$ race?
(A) 30.1
(B) 30
(C) 10
(D) 29.8
(E) It is impossible to determine. -/
theorem algebra_138799 (c t m : ‚Ñù)
    (h‚ÇÄ : c * 10 = t * 1000) (h‚ÇÅ : t * 20 = m * 1000) :
    c * 1000 - m * 1000 = 29.8 := by

soln_description:
$$
P=\frac{(n+1)(n+2) \ldots(2 n+1)}{2^{n}}=\frac{(2 n+1)!}{2^{n} \cdot n!}=\frac{(2 n+1)!}{2^{n} \cdot 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot \ldots \cdot n}=\frac{(2 n+1)!}{2 \cdot 4 \cdot \ldots \cdot 2 n}=1 \cdot 3 \cdot \ldots \cdot(2 n+1)
$$

$P$ is thus the product of all odd numbers from 1 to $2 n+1$ and is therefore an odd natural number.

import Mathlib
