theorem algebra_185847 (Œ± : Real) :
    Real.sin (6 * Œ±) / Real.sin (2 * Œ±) + Real.cos (6 * Œ± - Real.pi) / Real.cos (2 * Œ±) = 2 := by

soln_description:
When $n=1$, $\sin \frac{2\left[\frac{n+1}{4}\right] \pi}{n}=0=\frac{n-1}{n}$.
When $n=2$, $\sin \frac{2\left[\frac{n+1}{4}\right] \pi}{n}=0\frac{2}{3}=\frac{n-1}{n} \text {. }$

When $n=4$,
$$
\sin \frac{2\left[\frac{n+1}{4}\right] \pi}{n}=\sin \frac{\pi}{2}=1>\frac{3}{4}=\frac{n-1}{n} \text {. }
$$

When $n=5$, since $\sin x$ is a concave function on $[0, \pi]$, by Jensen's inequality we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin \frac{2\left[\frac{n+1}{4}\right] \pi}{n}=\sin \frac{2 \pi}{5}=\sin \frac{4 \times \frac{\pi}{2}}{5} \\
= & \sin \frac{4 \times \frac{\pi}{2}+1 \times 0}{5} \\
> & \frac{1}{5}\left(4 \times \sin \frac{\pi}{2}+1 \times \sin 0\right)=\frac{4}{5}=\frac{n-1}{n} .
\end{aligned}
$$

When $n \geqslant 6$, if $n \equiv-1(\bmod 4)$, then let $n=4 k-1\left(k \in \mathbf{N}_{+}\right)$.
By Jensen's inequality we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sin \frac{2\left[\frac{n+1}{4}\right] \pi}{n}=\sin \frac{2 k \pi}{4 k-1} \\
=\sin \frac{4 k \times \frac{\pi}{2}}{4 k-1}=\sin \frac{(4 k-2) \times \frac{\pi}{2}+1 \times \pi}{4 k-1} \\
\geqslant \frac{1}{4 k-1}\left[(4 k-2) \sin \frac{\pi}{2}+1 \times \sin \pi\right] \\
=\frac{4 k-2}{4 k-1}=\frac{n-1}{n} .
\end{array}
$$

If $n \neq-1(\bmod 4)$, then
$$
\frac{n-3}{4}\frac{n-1}{n} .
\end{array}
$$

In summary, the positive integer $n$ is all positive integers except 2.
informal_statement:

theorem inequalities_303424 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) :
    sin (2 * ‚åä(n + 1) / 4‚åã‚Çä * œÄ / n) ‚â• (n - 1) / n ‚Üî n ‚â† 2 := by

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{8}} \frac{x-\frac{1}{x}}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x=\int_{\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{8}} \frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x-\int \frac{1}{x \sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x= \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \int_{\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{8}} \frac{d\left(x^{2}+1\right)}{\sqrt{x^{2}+1}}-\int_{\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{8}} \frac{1}{x \sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x=\left.\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 \cdot \sqrt{x^{2}+1}\right|_{\sqrt{3}} ^{\sqrt{8}}-\int_{\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{8}} \frac{1}{x^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \sqrt{x^{2}+1}} d x= \\
& =\sqrt{(\sqrt{8})^{2}+1}-\sqrt{(\sqrt{3})^{2}+1}-\int_{\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{8}} \frac{1}{x^{2} \sqrt{1+\frac{1}{x^{2}}}} d x=\sqrt{9}-\sqrt{4}+\int_{\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{8}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{1}{x^{2}}}} d\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)= \\
& =3-2+\ln \left|\frac{1}{x}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{x^{2}}+1}\right|_{\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{8}}= \\
& =1+\ln \left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{8}}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{(\sqrt{8})^{2}}+1}\right|-\ln \left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{(\sqrt{3})^{2}}+1}\right|= \\
& =1+\ln \left|\frac{1+\sqrt{9}}{\sqrt{8}}\right|-\ln \left|\frac{1+\sqrt{4}}{\sqrt{3}}\right|=1+\ln \left|\frac{4}{2 \sqrt{2}}\right|-\ln \left|\frac{3}{\sqrt{3}}\right|= \\
& =1+\ln \sqrt{2}-\ln \sqrt{3}=1+\ln \sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Source ‚Äî "http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/?\?\?\?\?\?\?\?\?\?\?\?_ \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83\%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD\%D1\%82 $\% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 5 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 3 \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 80 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{~B} 0 \% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+4-11$ " Categories: Kuznetsov's Problem Book Integrals Problem 4 | Integrals

soln_description:
We first apply the arithmetic-geometric mean inequality to the terms $a+b$, $b+c$, $c+d$, and $d+a$, and then the quadratic-arithmetic mean inequality to the terms $a, b, c, d$, and obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
(a+b)(b+c)(c+d)(d+a) & \leq\left(\frac{(a+b)+(b+c)+(c+d)+(d+a)}{4}\right)^{4} \\
& =16\left(\frac{a+b+c+d}{4}\right)^{4} \leq 16\left(\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}}{4}\right)^{2}=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}\right)^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the first inequality, equality holds exactly for $a=c, b=d$, in the second inequality, equality holds exactly for $a=b=c=d$.

Thus, overall equality holds exactly for $a=b=c=d$.

(Clemens Heuberger)
informal_statement:
Show that

\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}\right)^{2} \geq(a+b)(b+c)(c+d)(d+a)
$$

for all positive real numbers \(a, b, c, d\).

When does equality hold?

(Georg Anegg)

    (a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2)^2 ‚â• (a + b) * (b + c) * (c + d) * (d + a) ‚àß ((a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2)^2 = (a + b) * (b + c) * (c + d) * (d + a) ‚Üî a = b ‚àß b = c ‚àß c = d) := by

soln_description:
20.19. Substituting $x=y=0$ into the original identity, we get $f(0)=$ $=2 f(0)$, i.e., $f(0)=0$. For any $x \in \mathbb{R}$ from the identity

$$
f(x+y)-f(x)=f(y)+2 x y \quad(y \in \mathbf{R})
$$

## we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}(x)=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x+y)-f(x)}{y}= & \lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(y)+2 x y}{y}= \\
& =2 x+\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(y)-f(0)}{y}=2 x+f^{\prime}(0)
\end{aligned}
$$

therefore, the sought functions must satisfy the condition

$$
f(x)=f(x)-f(0)=\int_{0}^{x} f^{\prime}(y) d y=x^{2}-f f^{\prime}(0) x_{1}
$$

Note that for any value $a \in \mathbb{R}$, the function $f(x)=x^{2}+a x$ satisfies the required identity in the problem.

/- 2. Let $a$ and $b$ be five-digit palindromes (without leading zeroes) such that $a<b$ and there are no other five-digit palindromes strictly between $a$ and $b$. What are all possible values of $b-a$ ? (A number is a palindrome if it reads the same forwards and backwards in base 10.) -/
theorem number_theory_169462 (a b : ‚Ñï) (ha : a ‚àà Finset.Icc 10000 99999) (hb : b ‚àà Finset.Icc 10000 99999)
    (h : Nat.digits 10 a = List.reverse (Nat.digits 10 a)) (h' : Nat.digits 10 b = List.reverse (Nat.digits 10 b))
    (h'' : a < b) (h''' : ‚àÄ x ‚àà Finset.Ioo a b, Nat.digits 10 x ‚â† List.reverse (Nat.digits 10 x)) :
    b - a = 11 ‚à® b - a = 100 ‚à® b - a = 110 := by

soln_description:
The norm of a polynomial $R(x)=c_{n} x^{n}+c_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+c_{1} x+c_{0}$ is defined as the number $|R|=\sqrt{c_{n}^{2}+c_{n-1}^{2}+\ldots+c_{0}^{2}}$ and we set

$R^{*}(x)=c_{0} x^{n}+c_{1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+c_{n-1} x+c_{n}$.

Lemma. For any polynomials $P$ and $Q$, the equality $|P Q|=\left|P Q^{*}\right|$ holds.

Proof. Let $P(x)=a_{n} x^{n}+a_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{1} x+a_{0}, Q(x)=b_{m} x^{m}+b_{m-1} x^{m-1}+\ldots+b_{1} x+b_{0}$. The coefficient $c_{k}$ of $x^{k}$ in the polynomial $P Q$ is the sum of the numbers $a_{i} b_{j}$ for which $i+j=k$. Therefore, the sum of the squares of these coefficients consists of terms of the form $\left(a_{i} b_{j}\right)^{2}$ (each appearing once - from the square of the number $c_{i+j}$) and double products of the form $2 a_{i} b_{j} a_{p} b_{q}$, where $i+j=p+q$ (also appearing once - from the same square). The coefficient of $x^{k}$ in the polynomial $P Q^{*}$ is the sum of the numbers $a_{i} b_{j}$ for which $i+(m-j)=k$, that is, $i-j=k-m$. Therefore, the sum of the squares of the coefficients of this polynomial consists of the same terms of the form $\left(a_{i} b_{j}\right)^{2}$ (each appearing once) and double products of the form $2 a_{i} b_{j} a_{p} b_{q}$, where $i-j=p-q$. But these are the same double products, since $i-j=p-q \Leftrightarrow i+q=j+p$.

Now consider the monic polynomials $P(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{1} x+a_{0}$ and $Q(x)=x^{m}+b_{m-1} x^{m-1}+\ldots+$ $b_{1} x+b_{0}$. Then

$Q^{*}(x)=b_{0} x^{m}+b_{1} x^{m-1}+\ldots+b_{m-1} x+1, P Q^{*}(x)=b_{0} x^{m+n}+\ldots+\left(a_{1}+a_{0} b_{m-1}\right) x+a_{0}$ and, therefore,

$|P Q|^{2}=\left|P Q^{*}\right|^{2} \geq a_{0}^{2}+b_{0}^{2}$.
informal_statement:
[Symmetry and Involutory Transformations] $[\quad$ Counting in Two Ways $\quad]$

## Authors: Galochkin A.I., Lyako O.

Given non-constant polynomials $P(x)$ and $Q(x)$, whose leading coefficients are equal to 1.

Prove that the sum of the squares of the coefficients of the polynomial $P(x) Q(x)$ is not less than the sum of the squares of the constant terms of $P(x)$ and $Q(x)$.

/- [Symmetry and Involutory Transformations] $[\quad$ Counting in Two Ways $\quad]$

## Authors: Galochkin A.I., Lyako O.

Given non-constant polynomials $P(x)$ and $Q(x)$, whose leading coefficients are equal to 1.

Prove that the sum of the squares of the coefficients of the polynomial $P(x) Q(x)$ is not less than the sum of the squares of the constant terms of $P(x)$ and $Q(x)$. -/
theorem algebra_212319 {P Q : Polynomial ‚Ñù} (hP : P.degree > 0) (hQ : Q.degree > 0)
    (hP1 : P.coeff P.natDegree = 1) (hQ1 : Q.coeff Q.natDegree = 1) :
    ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range ((P * Q).natDegree + 1), (P * Q).coeff i ^ 2 ‚â•
    (P.coeff 0) ^ 2 + (Q.coeff 0) ^ 2 := by

soln_description:
Answer: $[-\sqrt{2} ; \sqrt{2}+2 \sin 2]$. Solution. The domain of the function $y=f(x)$ is the interval [0,2]. We will prove that on the interval $(0 ; 2)$, the derivative $f'(x)$ is positive, and thus the function $f(x)$, continuous on $[0,2]$, is monotonically increasing. We have

$$
f'(x)=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2-x}}+2 \cos x
$$

Obviously, $f'(x)>0$ for $x \in\left(0 ; \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$, since all terms are positive. Let's check that $f'(x)>0$ also holds on the half-interval $\left[\frac{\pi}{2} ; 2\right)$. For this, in the following estimates, we will use the obvious inequalities $\sqrt{2}3$, as well as the monotonic decrease of the function $\cos x$ in the second quadrant. For all $x \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2} ; 2\right)$, we will have
$\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}>\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}>\frac{1}{2 \cdot 1.5}=\frac{1}{3}, \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2-x}} \geq \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2-\frac{\pi}{2}}}>\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}>\frac{1}{1.5}=\frac{2}{3}$ and $\cos x>\cos 2>\cos \frac{2 \pi}{3}=-\frac{1}{2}$. Thus, $f'(x)=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2-x}}+2 \cos x>\frac{1}{3}+\frac{2}{3}+2 \cdot\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=0$ for all $x \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2} ; 2\right)$. Therefore, the continuous function $f(x)$ is monotonically increasing on $[0 ; 2]$, from which the answer follows.
informal_statement: 11.5. Find the set of values of the function $y=\sqrt{x}-\sqrt{2-x}+2 \sin x$.

import Mathlib

/- 11.5. Find the set of values of the function $y=\sqrt{x}-\sqrt{2-x}+2 \sin x$. -/
theorem algebra_174483 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚àà Icc 0 2) :
    sqrt x - sqrt (2 - x) + 2 * sin x ‚àà Icc (-sqrt 2) (sqrt 2 + 2 * sin 2) := by

informal_statement: It is known that A is a two-digit number, and the remainder of $A^{2}$ divided by $15$ is $1$. The number of A that satisfies the condition is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___.
informal_proof:
Let $S$ be the set of two-digit natural numbers $A$ such that the remainder of $A^2$ divided by 15 is 1. Our goal is to find the number of elements in $S$.

The condition that $A$ is a two-digit number means that $A$ is in the range $[10, 99]$. The second condition is the modular congruence $A^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{15}$. Thus, we can define the set $S$ as:
$$ S = \{A \in \mathbb{N} \mid 10 \le A \le 99 \land A^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{15}\} $$
Let $I$ be the set of all natural numbers from 10 to 99, inclusive. The set $S$ can be equivalently described as the subset of $I$ containing all elements $A$ that satisfy the congruence $A^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{15}$.

Since $S$ is a subset of the finite set $I$, the number of elements in $S$ is found by counting how many numbers in $I$ satisfy the given congruence.

This is a finite computation. By directly checking each integer from 10 to 99, we can count the numbers that satisfy the condition. This exhaustive check confirms that there are exactly 24 such numbers. Therefore, the number of elements in $S$ is 24.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- It is known that A is a two-digit number, and the remainder of $A^{2}$ divided by $15$ is $1$. The number of A that satisfies the condition is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___. -/
theorem number_theory_4 :
    Set.ncard {A : ‚Ñï | A ‚àà Finset.Icc 10 99 ‚àß A^2 ‚â° 1 [MOD 15]} = 24 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_4 :
    Set.ncard {A : ‚Ñï | A ‚àà Finset.Icc 10 99 ‚àß A^2 ‚â° 1 [MOD 15]} = 24 := by
  have h1 : {A : ‚Ñï | A ‚àà Finset.Icc 10 99 ‚àß A^2 ‚â° 1 [MOD 15]} = Finset.filter (fun A => A^2 ‚â° 1 [MOD 15]) (Finset.Icc 10 99) := by
    ext A
    simp [Finset.mem_filter]
    <;> tauto
  rw [h1]
  rw [Set.ncard_coe_Finset]
  native_decide

soln_description:
Prove that if $P(z) \equiv Q(z) \cdot Q(-z)$, then
$P(-z) \equiv Q(-z) \cdot Q(z) \equiv P(z)$, i.e., $P(z)$ is an even function.
Conversely, if $P(z) \equiv 0$, then take $Q(z) \equiv 0$, so $P(z) \equiv Q(z) Q(-z)$. Now, for a non-zero polynomial $P(z)$ that is an even function, use mathematical induction on the number of non-zero roots $m$ of the polynomial $P(z)$ to prove that there exists a polynomial $Q(z)$ such that $P(z) \equiv Q(z) Q(-z)$.

When $m=0$, the polynomial $P(z)$ has the form $P(z)=a z^{n}, a \neq 0$. Since $P(z)$ is an even function, $n=2 k, k \in \mathbf{Z}^{+}$. Take the polynomial $Q(z)=b z^{k}$, where $b^{2}=(-1)^{k} a$. Because $a z^{n}=b z^{k} \cdot b(-z)^{k}$, the polynomial $Q(z)$ satisfies the given identity. Assume the conclusion holds for all positive integers less than $m$, and we will prove that the conclusion holds for $m$. In fact, if $\alpha$ is a non-zero root of the polynomial, then
$$
p(-\alpha)=p(\alpha)=0,
$$

thus $P(z)=(z-\alpha)(z+\alpha) R(z)$.
Here, $R(z)$ is an even function, because
$$
R(-z)\left[(-z)^{2}-\alpha^{2}\right] \equiv P(-z) \equiv P(z) \equiv R(z)\left(z^{2}-\alpha^{2}\right),
$$

By the induction hypothesis, there exists a polynomial $S(z)$ such that
$$
\begin{array}{c}
R(z) \equiv S(z) S(-z), \text { take } Q(z) \equiv \mathrm{i}(z-\alpha) S(z) \text {, then } \\
P(z) \equiv \mathrm{i}(z-\alpha) S(z) \cdot \mathrm{i}(-z-\alpha) S(-z) \equiv Q(z) Q(-z) .
\end{array}
$$

The proof is complete.
informal_statement:
Example 11. Prove: A polynomial $P(z)$ is an even function of $z \in \mathbf{C}$ if and only if there exists a polynomial $Q(z)$ such that $P(z) \equiv Q(z) \cdot Q(-z), z \in \mathbf{C}$.
(1979 Romanian Olympiad Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset

/- Example 11. Prove: A polynomial $P(z)$ is an even function of $z \in \mathbf{C}$ if and only if there exists a polynomial $Q(z)$ such that $P(z) \equiv Q(z) \cdot Q(-z), z \in \mathbf{C}$.
(1979 Romanian Olympiad Problem) -/
theorem algebra_257663 {P : Polynomial ‚ÑÇ} :
  Even P ‚Üî ‚àÉ Q : Polynomial ‚ÑÇ, ‚àÄ z : ‚ÑÇ, P.eval z = (Q.eval z) * (Q.eval (-z)) :=

soln_description:
Proof: Note that
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a b+b c+c a+1=(b+c) a+b c+1, \\
|a|<1, \\
f(1)=b+c+b c+1 \\
=(1+b)(1+c)>0 .
\end{array}
$$

Since $f(x)$ is a linear function, when $x \in(-1,1)$, we always have $f(x)>0$, i.e., when $|a|<1$, we have $a b+b c+c a+1>0$.
informal_statement:
Example 1 Let $|a|<1, |b|<1, |c|<1$.
$$
\text { Prove that } (1+a)(1+b)(1+c)>0 \text { and } (1-a)(1-b)(1-c)>0.
$$

Analysis: Treat any one of $a, b, c$ as a variable, and construct a linear function. For example, treat $a$ as a variable, and let $f(x)=(b+c) x+b c+1$. Therefore, it is only necessary to prove that $f(x)>0$ always holds within $(-1,1)$.
informal_proof:
We are given that `a`, `b`, and `c` are real numbers such that `|a| < 1`, `|b| < 1`, and `|c| < 1`. We need to prove two inequalities: `(1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c) > 0` and `(1 - a)(1 - b)(1 - c) > 0`.

First, let's prove that `(1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c) > 0`.
The condition `|a| < 1` is equivalent to the inequality `-1 < a < 1`. From this, we have `-1 < a`. Adding 1 to both sides gives `0 < 1 + a`.
Similarly, the condition `|b| < 1` implies `-1 < b`, which gives `0 < 1 + b`.
And the condition `|c| < 1` implies `-1 < c`, which gives `0 < 1 + c`.
We have now shown that `1 + a`, `1 + b`, and `1 + c` are all positive real numbers. The product of positive real numbers is positive. Therefore, `(1 + a)(1 + b)(1 + c) > 0`.

Next, let's prove that `(1 - a)(1 - b)(1 - c) > 0`.
From the condition `|a| < 1` (i.e., `-1 < a < 1`), we have `a < 1`. Subtracting `a` from both sides gives `0 < 1 - a`.
Similarly, `|b| < 1` implies `b < 1`, which gives `0 < 1 - b`.
And `|c| < 1` implies `c < 1`, which gives `0 < 1 - c`.
We have now shown that `1 - a`, `1 - b`, and `1 - c` are all positive real numbers. Their product must therefore also be positive. Hence, `(1 - a)(1 - b)(1 - c) > 0`.

Since we have proven both inequalities, the proof is complete.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1 Let $|a|<1, |b|<1, |c|<1$.
$$
\text { Prove that } (1+a)(1+b)(1+c)>0 \text { and } (1-a)(1-b)(1-c)>0.
$$

Analysis: Treat any one of $a, b, c$ as a variable, and construct a linear function. For example, treat $a$ as a variable, and let $f(x)=(b+c) x+b c+1$. Therefore, it is only necessary to prove that $f(x)>0$ always holds within $(-1,1)$. -/
theorem inequalities_301956 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : abs a < 1) (hb : abs b < 1) (hc : abs c < 1) :
    (1 + a) * (1 + b) * (1 + c) > 0 ‚àß (1 - a) * (1 - b) * (1 - c) > 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_301956 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : abs a < 1) (hb : abs b < 1) (hc : abs c < 1) :
    (1 + a) * (1 + b) * (1 + c) > 0 ‚àß (1 - a) * (1 - b) * (1 - c) > 0 := by
  have ha1 : -1 < a := by linarith [abs_lt.mp ha]
  have ha2 : a < 1 := by linarith [abs_lt.mp ha]
  have hb1 : -1 < b := by linarith [abs_lt.mp hb]
  have hb2 : b < 1 := by linarith [abs_lt.mp hb]
  have hc1 : -1 < c := by linarith [abs_lt.mp hc]
  have hc2 : c < 1 := by linarith [abs_lt.mp hc]
  have h1 : 1 + a > 0 := by linarith
  have h2 : 1 + b > 0 := by linarith
  have h3 : 1 + c > 0 := by linarith
  have h4 : (1 + a) * (1 + b) * (1 + c) > 0 := by
    apply mul_pos
    apply mul_pos
    all_goals linarith
  have h5 : 1 - a > 0 := by linarith
  have h6 : 1 - b > 0 := by linarith
  have h7 : 1 - c > 0 := by linarith
  have h8 : (1 - a) * (1 - b) * (1 - c) > 0 := by
    apply mul_pos
    apply mul_pos
    all_goals linarith
  constructor
  ¬∑ exact h4
  ¬∑ exact h8

soln_description:
Substitute $y$ into the other equation.
\[2\log{x} = \log{2x}\]
Using a logarithm property,
\[2\log{x} = \log{2} + \log{x}\]
Subtract both sides by $\log{x}$ to get
\[\log{x}=\log{2}\]
Thus, $x=2$.  Since both $2\log{x}$ and $\log{2x}$ are functions, there is only one corresponding y-value, so the answer is $\boxed{\textbf{(B)}}$.
informal_statement:
Consider the graphs of $y=2\log{x}$ and $y=\log{2x}$. We may say that:
$\textbf{(A)}\ \text{They do not intersect}\qquad \\ \textbf{(B)}\ \text{They intersect at 1 point only}\qquad \\ \textbf{(C)}\ \text{They intersect at 2 points only} \qquad \\ \textbf{(D)}\ \text{They intersect at a finite number of points but greater than 2} \qquad \\ \textbf{(E)}\ \text{They coincide}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Consider the graphs of $y=2\log{x}$ and $y=\log{2x}$. We may say that:
$\textbf{(A)}\ \text{They do not intersect}\qquad \\ \textbf{(B)}\ \text{They intersect at 1 point only}\qquad \\ \textbf{(C)}\ \text{They intersect at 2 points only} \qquad \\ \textbf{(D)}\ \text{They intersect at a finite number of points but greater than 2} \qquad \\ \textbf{(E)}\ \text{They coincide}$ -/
theorem algebra_98259 (f g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hf : f = fun x => 2 * log x) (hg : g = fun x => log (2 * x)) :
    ‚àÉ! x, f x = g x := by

soln_description:
Observe que

$$
2^{8}+2^{11}+2^{n}=\left(2^{4}\right)^{2}+2 \times 2^{4} \times 2^{6}+\left(2^{\frac{n}{2}}\right)^{2}
$$

Logo, se $n=12$, temos

$$
2^{8}+2^{11}+2^{12}=\left(2^{4}+2^{6}\right)^{2}
$$

Logo $n=12$ √© uma solu√ß√£o.

Solu√ß√£o Geral: $\operatorname{Se} 2^{8}+2^{11}+2^{n}=k^{2}$, ent√£o:

$$
\begin{aligned}
2^{8}+2^{3} \times 2^{8}+2^{n} & =k^{2} \\
9 \times 2^{8}+2^{n} & =k^{2} \\
2^{n} & =k^{2}-\left(3 \times 2^{4}\right)^{2} \\
2^{n} & =\left(k-3 \times 2^{4}\right)\left(k+3 \times 2^{4}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Logo, $\left(k-3 \times 2^{4}\right)$ e $\left(k+3 \times 2^{4}\right)$ s√£o pot√™ncias de 2 , ou seja:

$$
k+3 \times 2^{4}=2^{a}, k-3 \times 2^{4}=2^{b} \text { e } a+b=n
$$

Temos:

$$
2^{a}-2^{b}=\left(k+3 \times 2^{4}\right)-\left(k-3 \times 2^{4}\right)=3 \times 2^{5}=96
$$

Examinemos a lista das pot√™ncias de 2:

$$
1,4,8,16,32,64,128,256, \cdots
$$

Constatamos que $128-32=96$. Logo, $a=7, b=5$ e $n=12$.
informal_statement: Determine um valor de $n$ para o qual o numero $2^{8}+2^{11}+2^{n}$ seja um quadrado perfeito.
informal_proof:
We want to prove that 12 is the least natural number `n` such that `2^8 + 2^11 + 2^n` is a perfect square.

To establish this, we must prove two things:
1.  The number `2^8 + 2^11 + 2^12` is a perfect square.
2.  For any natural number `n < 12`, the number `2^8 + 2^11 + 2^n` is not a perfect square.

**Part 1: Show that `n=12` gives a perfect square.**

Let `n = 12`. We evaluate the expression:
`2^8 + 2^11 + 2^12 = 256 + 2048 + 4096 = 6400`.
We observe that `6400 = 80^2`.
Thus, for `n=12`, the expression is a perfect square, with `k=80`.

**Part 2: Show that for any `n < 12`, the expression is not a perfect square.**

We proceed by contradiction. Assume there exists a natural number `n < 12` for which `2^8 + 2^11 + 2^n` is a perfect square. Let this square be `k^2` for some integer `k`.
The condition `n < 12` means `n` must be one of the integers `0, 1, 2, ..., 11`. We will examine each case.

Let `V_n = 2^8 + 2^11 + 2^n = 256 + 2048 + 2^n = 2304 + 2^n`. We need to show that for `n \in \{0, 1, ..., 11\}`, `V_n` is not a perfect square. We can do this by showing that `V_n` lies strictly between two consecutive perfect squares.

*   **Case n=0:** `V_0 = 2304 + 2^0 = 2304 + 1 = 2305`. Since `48^2 = 2304` and `49^2 = 2401`, we have `48^2 < 2305 < 49^2`. Thus, 2305 is not a perfect square.
*   **Case n=1:** `V_1 = 2304 + 2^1 = 2306`. We have `48^2 < 2306 < 49^2`.
*   **Case n=2:** `V_2 = 2304 + 2^2 = 2308`. We have `48^2 < 2308 < 49^2`.
*   **Case n=3:** `V_3 = 2304 + 2^3 = 2312`. We have `48^2 < 2312 < 49^2`.
*   **Case n=4:** `V_4 = 2304 + 2^4 = 2320`. We have `48^2 < 2320 < 49^2`.
*   **Case n=5:** `V_5 = 2304 + 2^5 = 2336`. We have `48^2 < 2336 < 49^2`.
*   **Case n=6:** `V_6 = 2304 + 2^6 = 2368`. We have `48^2 < 2368 < 49^2`.
*   **Case n=7:** `V_7 = 2304 + 2^7 = 2432`. Since `49^2 = 2401` and `50^2 = 2500`, we have `49^2 < 2432 < 50^2`.
*   **Case n=8:** `V_8 = 2304 + 2^8 = 2560`. Since `50^2 = 2500` and `51^2 = 2601`, we have `50^2 < 2560 < 51^2`.
*   **Case n=9:** `V_9 = 2304 + 2^9 = 2816`. Since `53^2 = 2809` and `54^2 = 2916`, we have `53^2 < 2816 < 54^2`.
*   **Case n=10:** `V_{10} = 2304 + 2^{10} = 3328`. Since `57^2 = 3249` and `58^2 = 3364`, we have `57^2 < 3328 < 58^2`.
*   **Case n=11:** `V_{11} = 2304 + 2^{11} = 4352`. Since `65^2 = 4225` and `66^2 = 4356`, we have `65^2 < 4352 < 66^2`.

In every case for `n < 12`, the value of `2^8 + 2^11 + 2^n` is not a perfect square. This contradicts our assumption that such an `n` exists. Therefore, there are no solutions for `n < 12`.

Since `n=12` is a solution and no smaller natural number `n` is a solution, we conclude that 12 is the least natural number for which the given expression is a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine um valor de $n$ para o qual o numero $2^{8}+2^{11}+2^{n}$ seja um quadrado perfeito. -/
theorem number_theory_243835 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    IsLeast {n | ‚àÉ k, (2^8 + 2^11 + 2^n) = k^2} 12 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_243835 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    IsLeast {n | ‚àÉ k, (2^8 + 2^11 + 2^n) = k^2} 12 := by 
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that 12 is in the set
    use 80
    all_goals norm_num
  ¬∑ -- Show that no smaller element is in the set
    intro n hn
    rcases hn with ‚ü®k, hk‚ü©
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    have h1 : n < 12 := by linarith
    interval_cases n <;> try { 
      by_cases h' : k ‚â§ 128
      ¬∑ interval_cases k <;> omega
      ¬∑ 
        push_neg at h'
        have h7 : k > 128 := by linarith
        have h8 : k ‚â§ 256 := by
          nlinarith
        interval_cases k <;> omega
    }
    <;> try { nlinarith }

soln_description: Let one of the roots be $r_1$. Also, define $x$ such that $2+x=r_1$. Thus, we have $f(2+x)=f(r_1)=0$ and $f(2+x)=f(2-x)$. Therefore, we have $f(2-x)=0$, and $2-x$ is also a root. Let this root be $r_2$. The sum $r_1+r_2=2+x+2-x=4$. Similarly, we can let $r_3$ be a root and define $y$ such that $2+y=r_3$, and we will find $2-y$ is also a root, say, $r_4$, so $r_3+r_4=2+y+2-y=4$. Therefore, $r_1+r_2+r_3+r_4=4+4=8, \boxed{\text{E}}$.
informal_statement:
The [function](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Function) $f(x)$ satisfies $f(2+x)=f(2-x)$ for all real numbers $x$. If the equation $f(x)=0$ has exactly four distinct real [roots](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Root_(polynomial)), then the sum of these roots is
$\mathrm{(A) \ }0 \qquad \mathrm{(B) \ }2 \qquad \mathrm{(C) \ } 4 \qquad \mathrm{(D) \ }6 \qquad \mathrm{(E) \ } 8$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The [function](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Function) $f(x)$ satisfies $f(2+x)=f(2-x)$ for all real numbers $x$. If the equation $f(x)=0$ has exactly four distinct real [roots](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Root_(polynomial)), then the sum of these roots is
$\mathrm{(A) \ }0 \qquad \mathrm{(B) \ }2 \qquad \mathrm{(C) \ } 4 \qquad \mathrm{(D) \ }6 \qquad \mathrm{(E) \ } 8$ -/
theorem algebra_94993 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (h : ‚àÄ x, f (2 + x) = f (2 - x)) (r : Finset ‚Ñù)
    (hr : r.card = 4) (hrr : ‚àÄ x ‚àà r, f x = 0) :
    ‚àë x ‚àà r, x = 8 := by

soln_description: [Solution] The two curves intersect at only one point, which means the quadratic equation $x^{2}+4(m x+1)^{2}=1$ has two equal roots, thus the discriminant is zero. That is, $\Delta=(8 m)^{2}-4\left(4 m^{2}+1\right) \cdot 3=0$, solving this gives $m^{2}=\frac{3}{4}$. Therefore, the answer is $(C)$.
informal_statement:
26-34 If the line $y=m x+1$ intersects the ellipse $x^{2}+4 y^{2}=1$ at one point (tangent), then the value of $m^{2}$ is
(A) $\frac{1}{2}$.
(B) $\frac{2}{3}$.
(C) $\frac{3}{4}$.
(D) $\frac{4}{5}$.
(E) $\frac{5}{6}$.
(22nd American High School Mathematics Examination, 1971)
informal_proof:
We are given that there exists a unique real number `x` satisfying the equation `x^2 + 4(mx + 1)^2 = 1`.

First, let's expand and rearrange this equation.
`x^2 + 4(m^2x^2 + 2mx + 1) = 1`
`x^2 + 4m^2x^2 + 8mx + 4 = 1`
`(1 + 4m^2)x^2 + 8mx + 3 = 0`

This shows that any solution `y` to the original equation must be a root of the quadratic equation `(1 + 4m^2)y^2 + 8my + 3 = 0`. Let's call this equation (*).

Since `m` is a real number, `m^2 ‚â• 0`, which implies `4m^2 ‚â• 0`, and thus the leading coefficient `1 + 4m^2 ‚â• 1`. Therefore, `1 + 4m^2` is non-zero, and (*) is a true quadratic equation.

A quadratic equation can have at most two distinct real roots. The initial hypothesis states that the equation has a unique solution `x`. This means that the quadratic equation (*) must also have a unique solution, which is `x`. This occurs when the two roots of the quadratic are identical.

Let the roots of the quadratic equation (*) be `r‚ÇÅ` and `r‚ÇÇ`. From the uniqueness condition, we must have `r‚ÇÅ = r‚ÇÇ = x`.

According to Vieta's formulas, the sum of the roots of a quadratic equation `Ay^2 + By + C = 0` is given by `-B/A`. In our case, `A = 1 + 4m^2` and `B = 8m`. Therefore, the sum of the roots is:
`r‚ÇÅ + r‚ÇÇ = - (8m) / (1 + 4m^2)`

Since `r‚ÇÅ = r‚ÇÇ = x`, we can substitute `x` into this relation:
`x + x = - (8m) / (1 + 4m^2)`
`2x = - (8m) / (1 + 4m^2)`
`x = - (4m) / (1 + 4m^2)`

Now we have an expression for `x` in terms of `m`. We can substitute this expression back into the quadratic equation (*) that `x` must satisfy:
`(1 + 4m^2)x^2 + 8mx + 3 = 0`
`(1 + 4m^2) * (- (4m) / (1 + 4m^2))^2 + 8m * (- (4m) / (1 + 4m^2)) + 3 = 0`
`(1 + 4m^2) * (16m^2 / (1 + 4m^2)^2) - (32m^2 / (1 + 4m^2)) + 3 = 0`

Simplifying the first term, we get:
`16m^2 / (1 + 4m^2) - 32m^2 / (1 + 4m^2) + 3 = 0`
`-16m^2 / (1 + 4m^2) + 3 = 0`

Now, we solve for `m^2`:
`3 = 16m^2 / (1 + 4m^2)`
`3(1 + 4m^2) = 16m^2`
`3 + 12m^2 = 16m^2`
`3 = 16m^2 - 12m^2`
`3 = 4m^2`
`m^2 = 3/4`

Thus, we have shown that `m^2 = 3/4`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 26-34 If the line $y=m x+1$ intersects the ellipse $x^{2}+4 y^{2}=1$ at one point (tangent), then the value of $m^{2}$ is
(A) $\frac{1}{2}$.
(B) $\frac{2}{3}$.
(C) $\frac{3}{4}$.
(D) $\frac{4}{5}$.
(E) $\frac{5}{6}$.
(22nd American High School Mathematics Examination, 1971) -/
theorem algebra_153738 (m : ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÉ! x, x^2 + 4 * (m * x + 1)^2 = 1) :
    m^2 = 3 / 4 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_153738 (m : ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÉ! x, x^2 + 4 * (m * x + 1)^2 = 1) :
    m^2 = 3 / 4 := by
  rcases h with ‚ü®x, hx, h1‚ü©
  have eq1 : x^2 + 4 * (m * x + 1)^2 = 1 := hx
  have eq2 : (1 + 4 * m^2) * x^2 + 8 * m * x + 3 = 0 := by
    nlinarith [eq1]
  have h' : ‚àÄ y, y^2 + 4 * (m * y + 1)^2 = 1 ‚Üí y = x := h1
  -- The equation has only one solution, hence discriminant must be zero.
  have eq3 : ‚àÄ y, y^2 + 4 * (m * y + 1)^2 = 1 ‚Üí (1 + 4 * m^2) * y^2 + 8 * m * y + 3 = 0 := by
    intro y hy
    nlinarith [hy]
  have eq4 : (1 + 4 * m^2) ‚â† 0 := by
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * (1 + 4 * m^2)), sq_nonneg (8 * m * x + 3), sq_nonneg (m), sq_nonneg (x * 2 * m + 1)]
  have y2 : ( - (8 * m) / (1 + 4 * m^2) - x )^2 + 4 * (m * ( - (8 * m) / (1 + 4 * m^2) - x ) + 1)^2 = 1 := by
    specialize h' ( - (8 * m) / (1 + 4 * m^2) - x ) (by
      field_simp [eq2, eq4] at *
      nlinarith [eq2])
    rw [h'] at *
    field_simp [eq4] at *
    nlinarith [eq2]
  -- So from above and the uniqueness, they must satisfy x
  -- Hence, we can get y' = x. Therefore to solve.
  have eq6 : - (8 * m) / (1 + 4 * m^2) - x = x := by
    specialize h1 ( - (8 * m) / (1 + 4 * m^2) - x ) y2
    linarith
  field_simp [eq4] at eq6
  have h2 : 16 * m^2 - 12 = 0 := by
    nlinarith [eq6, eq2]
  nlinarith [h2]

soln_description:
1. $\frac{1}{8}$.

From the problem, we know that the parabolas
$$
y=x^{2}+2 a \text { and } x=y^{2}+2 a
$$

are tangent to each other, and $y=x$ is their common tangent line.
Therefore, $a=\frac{1}{8}$.
informal_statement:
1. For the system of inequalities about real numbers $x, y$
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
y \geqslant x^{2}+2 a, \\
x \geqslant y^{2}+2 a
\end{array}\right.
$$

to have a unique solution, the values of the parameter $a$ are
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 1. For the system of inequalities about real numbers $x, y$
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
y \geqslant x^{2}+2 a, \\
x \geqslant y^{2}+2 a
\end{array}\right.
$$

to have a unique solution, the values of the parameter $a$ are -/
theorem inequalities_320642 (a : ‚Ñù) :
  (‚àÉ! x : ‚Ñù, ‚àÉ! y : ‚Ñù,
    y ‚â• x^2 + 2 * a ‚àß x ‚â• y^2 + 2 * a) ‚Üî a = 1 / 8 := by

import Mathlib

/- 6 The sequence $a_{n}$ satisfy $a_{n}=a_{n-1}+n^{2}$ and $a_{0}=2009$. Find $a_{\text {so }}$.
(A) 42434
(B) 42925
(C) 44934
(D) 45029
(E) 45359 -/
theorem algebra_287644 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ n, a (n + 1) = a n + (n + 1)^2) (h‚ÇÅ : a 0 = 2009) :
    a 100 = 44934 := by

soln_description:
1. Let \( 4 + p_1 p_2 = x^2 \) and \( 4 + p_1 p_3 = y^2 \). This implies:
   \[
   p_1 p_2 = x^2 - 4 = (x-2)(x+2)
   \]
   and
   \[
   p_1 p_3 = y^2 - 4 = (y-2)(y+2)
   \]

2. Since \( p_1, p_2, p_3 \) are primes, and \( p_2 \neq p_3 \), we need to consider the factorization of \( (x-2)(x+2) \) and \( (y-2)(y+2) \) into products of primes.

3. Without loss of generality, assume \( p_2 > p_3 \). We need to find values of \( x \) and \( y \) such that both \( (x-2)(x+2) \) and \( (y-2)(y+2) \) are products of primes.

4. Consider the possible values for \( x \) and \( y \):
   - If \( p_1 = x+2 \), then \( p_2 = x-2 \).
   - If \( p_1 = x-2 \), then \( p_2 = x+2 \).

5. Similarly, for \( y \):
   - If \( p_1 = y+2 \), then \( p_3 = y-2 \).
   - If \( p_1 = y-2 \), then \( p_3 = y+2 \).

6. We need to find all triplets \( (p_1, p_2, p_3) \) such that each element is a prime number. Consider the triplet \( (p, p+4, p-4) \) and check for primality.

7. Taking modulo 3, we observe that one element of the triplet must be 3 for it to be prime. Therefore, let \( p_3 = 3 \).

8. If \( p_3 = 3 \), then:
   - \( 4 + p_1 \cdot 3 = y^2 \)
   - \( p_1 \cdot 3 = y^2 - 4 \)
   - \( p_1 = \frac{y^2 - 4}{3} \)

9. We need \( \frac{y^2 - 4}{3} \) to be a prime number. Check for small values of \( y \):
   - If \( y = 5 \), then \( p_1 = \frac{5^2 - 4}{3} = \frac{25 - 4}{3} = 7 \), which is a prime.
   - Therefore, \( p_1 = 7 \).

10. Now, check for \( p_2 \):
    - \( 4 + 7 \cdot p_2 = x^2 \)
    - \( 7 \cdot p_2 = x^2 - 4 \)
    - \( p_2 = \frac{x^2 - 4}{7} \)

11. We need \( \frac{x^2 - 4}{7} \) to be a prime number. Check for small values of \( x \):
    - If \( x = 11 \), then \( p_2 = \frac{11^2 - 4}{7} = \frac{121 - 4}{7} = 17 \), which is a prime.
    - Therefore, \( p_2 = 11 \).

12. Thus, the only triplet that satisfies the conditions is \( (7, 11, 3) \).

13. Since \( p_2 \neq p_3 \), the other possible triplet is \( (7, 3, 11) \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{ (7, 11, 3) } \) and \( (7, 3, 11) \).
informal_statement: Let $p_1,p_2,p_3$ be primes with $p_2\neq p_3$ such that $4+p_1p_2$ and $4+p_1p_3$ are perfect squares. Find all possible values of $p_1,p_2,p_3$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p_1,p_2,p_3$ be primes with $p_2\neq p_3$ such that $4+p_1p_2$ and $4+p_1p_3$ are perfect squares. Find all possible values of $p_1,p_2,p_3$. -/
theorem number_theory_62210 (p1 p2 p3 : ‚Ñï) (hp1 : p1.Prime) (hp2 : p2.Prime)
    (hp3 : p3.Prime) (hne : p2 ‚â† p3) (h1 : ‚àÉ m, m^2 = 4 + p1 * p2) (h2 : ‚àÉ n, n^2 = 4 + p1 * p3) :
    (p1, p2, p3) = (7, 11, 3) := by

informal_statement: The base 5 number $34x1_5$ is divisible by 31.  What is the digit $x$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The base 5 number $34x1_5$ is divisible by 31.  What is the digit $x$? -/
theorem number_theory_11103 (x : ‚Ñï) :
    31 ‚à£ Nat.ofDigits 5 [1, x, 4, 3] ‚Üî x = 4 := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let $v$ be the speed of the train expressed in $\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$, and $s$ be its length in meters. Then from the condition of the problem we have:

$$
v=\frac{s}{8} \text { and } v=\frac{s+480}{32} \text {. }
$$

From here we get $s=160 \mathrm{~m}$ and $v=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}(=72 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$ ).
informal_statement: 3. Calculate the speed and length of the train that passes a stationary observer in 8 seconds, and passes a platform 480 meters long in 12 seconds.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Calculate the speed and length of the train that passes a stationary observer in 8 seconds, and passes a platform 480 meters long in 12 seconds. -/
theorem algebra_255979 (l v : ‚Ñù) (hl : l > 0) (hv : v > 0)
    (h1 : l / v = 8) (h2 : (l + 480) / v = 12) :
    v = 20 ‚àß l = 160 := by

soln_description:
„ÄêSolution„ÄëSolve: $2016 \times\left(\frac{8}{7 \times 9}-\frac{1}{8}\right)$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=2016 \times \frac{8}{7 \times 9}-\frac{1}{8} \times 2016 \\
=256-252 \\
=4
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the answer is: 4 .
informal_statement: 1. (8 points) The calculation result of the expression $2016 \times\left(\frac{8}{7 \times 9}-\frac{1}{8}\right)$ is
informal_proof:
We want to show that $2016 \times\left(\frac{8}{7 \times 9}-\frac{1}{8}\right) = 4$.

We will prove this by evaluating the expression on the left-hand side. First, using the distributive property of multiplication over subtraction, we can expand the expression:
$$ 2016 \times\left(\frac{8}{7 \times 9}-\frac{1}{8}\right) = \left(2016 \times \frac{8}{7 \times 9}\right) - \left(2016 \times \frac{1}{8}\right) $$
Now, let's compute each term separately.

For the first term, we simplify the denominator: $7 \times 9 = 63$. The term becomes:
$$ 2016 \times \frac{8}{63} $$
We can rewrite this as $\frac{2016}{63} \times 8$. Since $2016 \div 63 = 32$, this simplifies to:
$$ 32 \times 8 = 256 $$
For the second term, we compute:
$$ 2016 \times \frac{1}{8} = \frac{2016}{8} $$
Since $2016 \div 8 = 252$, this term is equal to 252.

Finally, we substitute these results back into the expanded expression:
$$ 256 - 252 = 4 $$
Thus, we have shown that the left-hand side equals 4, which completes the proof.

soln_description:
17.16. Note that $a_{0}=0, a_{1}=1$, and let's prove the validity of the equality $a_{n+2}=4 a_{n+1}-a_{n}$ for each $n \in \mathbf{Z}^{+}$ (from which we will sequentially obtain that each of the numbers $a_{2}, a_{3}, a_{4}, \ldots$ is also an integer). Indeed, let

$$
\alpha=(2+\sqrt{3})^{n} /(2 \sqrt{3}), \quad \beta=(2-\sqrt{3})^{n} /(2 \sqrt{3})
$$

then we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{n} & =\alpha-\beta \\
a_{n+1} & =(2+\sqrt{3}) \alpha-(2-\sqrt{3}) \beta \\
a_{n+2} & =(2+\sqrt{3})^{2} \alpha-(2-\sqrt{3})^{2} \beta-(7+4 \sqrt{3}) \alpha-(7-4 \sqrt{3}) \beta= \\
& =(8+4 \sqrt{3}) \alpha-(8-4 \sqrt{3}) \beta-(\alpha+\beta)=4 a_{n+1}-a_{n} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since

$$
a_{n+2}=a_{n+1}-a_{n}(\bmod 3)
$$

and the remainders of the first 8 terms of the sequence $a_{0}$, $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots$ when divided by 3 are respectively $0,1,1,0,2,2,0,1$, then

$$
a_{6}=a_{0}(\bmod 3), a_{2}=a_{1}(\bmod 3)
$$

and, generally,

$$
a_{n+0} \equiv a_{n}(\bmod 3)
$$

Thus, in this sequence, the remainder 0 when divided by 3 is given by terms of the form $a_{3 k}$, where $k \in \mathbf{Z}^{+}$, and only they. Since $(2+\sqrt{3})(2-\sqrt{3})=1$, the following equality holds

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_21_03a501298610b72904feg-290.jpg?height=110&width=992&top_left_y=1693&top_left_x=78)

10 Edited by I. N. Sergeev
from which it follows that for negative values of $n$ the numbers $a_{n}$ are also integers, and $a_{n} \equiv 0(\bmod 3)$ if and only if $n=0(\bmod 3)$.

soln_description:
Prompt: If there exists $n>1\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$, such that $n \mid\left(2^{n}-1\right)$.
Since $2^{n}-1$ is an odd number, $n$ must be odd. Let $p$ be the smallest prime factor of $n$. Then $2^{n} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$. By Fermat's Little Theorem, we know $2^{p-1} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$. Let the order of 2 modulo $p$ be $\lambda$. Then $\lambda|n, \lambda|(p-1) \Rightarrow \lambda \mid(n, p-1)$. Since $p$ is the smallest prime factor of $n$, then $(n, p-1)=1$. Hence $\lambda=1$.
Thus, $2 \equiv 1(\bmod p) \Rightarrow p \mid 1$, which is a contradiction.
2. Let $q$ be a prime factor of the Fermat number $F_{n}=2^{2^{n}}+1$. Prove that when $n>1$, $2^{n+2} \mid(q-1)$.
Hint: First prove a lemma.
Lemma Let $v$ be a positive integer greater than 1, and $q$ be an odd prime factor of $v^{2^{m}}+1$. Then $2^{m+1} \mid(q-1)$.
Proof: According to the condition,
$$
v^{2^{m}} \equiv-1(\bmod q) \Rightarrow v^{2^{m+1}} \equiv 1(\bmod q).
$$

Let the order of $v$ modulo $q$ be $\lambda$. Then $\lambda \mid 2^{m+1}$.
But $\lambda \nmid 2^{m}$, so $\lambda=2^{m+1}$.
By Fermat's Little Theorem, we know $v^{q-1} \equiv 1(\bmod q)$.
Therefore, $2^{m+1} \mid(q-1)$.
Back to the original problem.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { By } F_{n-1}^{2^{n+1}} \equiv\left[\left(2^{2^{n-1}}+1\right)^{2}\right]^{2^{n}} \equiv\left(2^{2^{n-1}+1}\right)^{2^{n}} \\
\equiv\left(2^{2^{n}}\right)^{2^{n-1}}+1 \equiv(-1)^{2^{n-1}}+1 \equiv-1\left(\bmod F_{n}\right),
\end{array}
$$

we know $q \mid\left(F_{n-1}^{2^{n+1}}+1\right)$.
According to the lemma, $2^{n+2} \mid(q-1)$.

## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 1}\left(\frac{e^{\sin \pi x}-1}{x-1}\right)^{x^{2}+1}=\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{e^{\sin \pi x}-1}{x-1}\right)^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} x^{2}+1}= \\
& =\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{e^{\sin \pi x}-1}{x-1}\right)^{1^{2}+1}=\left(\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{e^{\sin \pi x}-1}{x-1}\right)^{2}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$x=y+1 \Rightarrow y=x-1$

$x \rightarrow 1 \Rightarrow y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left(\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\sin \pi(y+1)}-1}{(y+1)-1}\right)^{2}=\left(\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\sin (\pi y+\pi)}-1}{y}\right)^{2}= \\
& =\left(\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{-\sin \pi y}-1}{y}\right)^{2}=
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$e^{-\sin \pi y}-1 \sim -\sin \pi y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(-\sin \pi y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$$
=\left(\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{-\sin \pi y}{y}\right)^{2}=
$$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\sin \pi y \sim \pi y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(\pi y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$=\left(\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{-\pi y}{y}\right)^{2}=(-\pi)^{2}=\pi^{2}$

soln_description:
Solve
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
3 b=1 \\
-3 a+2 b=2 \\
a-b+c=-3
\end{array}\right.
$$

to get
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a=\frac{1}{3} \\
b=\frac{3}{2} \\
c=-\frac{11}{6}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Thus,
$$
S_{n}=\frac{1}{3} n^{3}+\frac{3}{2} n^{2}-\frac{11}{6} n .
$$

In general, if
$$
a_{\mathrm{n}}=b_{1} n^{\mathrm{p}}+b_{2} n^{\mathrm{p}-1}+\cdots+b_{\mathrm{p}}
$$

is a polynomial of degree $p$ in $n$, then $S_{n}$ is a polynomial of degree $p+1$ in $n$:
$$
S_{n}=c_{1} n^{\mathrm{P}+1}+c_{2} n^{\mathrm{D}}+\cdots+c_{\mathrm{p}} n .
$$
Hence, we have
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{c}
C_{\mathrm{p}+1}^{1} c_{1}=b_{1}, \\
-C_{\mathrm{p}+1}^{2} c_{1}+C_{\mathrm{p}}^{1} c_{2}=b_{2}, \\
C_{\mathrm{p}+1}^{\mathrm{s}} c_{1}-C_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} c_{2}+C_{\mathrm{p}-1}^{1} c_{3}=b_{3}, \\
\cdots \cdots \\
(-1)^{p} c_{1}+(-1)^{\mathrm{D}-1} c_{2}+\cdots+c_{\mathrm{D}-2} \\
-c_{p-1}+c_{p}=b_{p} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Solving this system of equations yields $c_{1}, c_{2}, \cdots, c_{p}$, which allows us to find the expression for $S_{\mathbf{n}}$.
informal_statement:
Example 4. Let $a_{\mathrm{n}}=n^{2}+2 n-3$ : Find $S_{\mathrm{s}}$.

Translate the text above into English, please keep the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
informal_proof:
Let the sequence $(a_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ be defined by $a_n = n^2 + 2n - 3$. We want to prove that for any natural number $n$, the sum $S_n = \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i$ is given by the formula:
$$ S_n = \frac{1}{3}n^3 + \frac{3}{2}n^2 - \frac{11}{6}n $$
We will prove this by mathematical induction on $n$.

**Base Case:** For $n=0$, the sum is over an empty set of indices, so it is 0.
$$ S_0 = \sum_{i=1}^{0} a_i = 0 $$
The formula gives:
$$ \frac{1}{3}(0)^3 + \frac{3}{2}(0)^2 - \frac{11}{6}(0) = 0 $$
Since both sides are equal to 0, the formula holds for $n=0$.

**Inductive Step:** Assume that the formula holds for some natural number $k \geq 0$. That is, assume the inductive hypothesis:
$$ S_k = \sum_{i=1}^{k} a_i = \frac{1}{3}k^3 + \frac{3}{2}k^2 - \frac{11}{6}k $$
We must show that the formula also holds for $n=k+1$. We need to prove:
$$ S_{k+1} = \sum_{i=1}^{k+1} a_i = \frac{1}{3}(k+1)^3 + \frac{3}{2}(k+1)^2 - \frac{11}{6}(k+1) $$
We start by expressing $S_{k+1}$ in terms of $S_k$:
$$ S_{k+1} = \sum_{i=1}^{k+1} a_i = \left(\sum_{i=1}^{k} a_i\right) + a_{k+1} = S_k + a_{k+1} $$
Using the inductive hypothesis for $S_k$ and the definition of the sequence for $a_{k+1} = (k+1)^2 + 2(k+1) - 3$, we have:
$$ S_{k+1} = \left(\frac{1}{3}k^3 + \frac{3}{2}k^2 - \frac{11}{6}k\right) + \left((k+1)^2 + 2(k+1) - 3\right) $$
Now, we simplify this expression. First, expand the terms for $a_{k+1}$:
$$ (k+1)^2 + 2(k+1) - 3 = (k^2 + 2k + 1) + (2k + 2) - 3 = k^2 + 4k $$
Substituting this back into the expression for $S_{k+1}$:
$$ S_{k+1} = \frac{1}{3}k^3 + \frac{3}{2}k^2 - \frac{11}{6}k + k^2 + 4k $$
Combine like terms:
$$ S_{k+1} = \frac{1}{3}k^3 + \left(\frac{3}{2} + 1\right)k^2 + \left(4 - \frac{11}{6}\right)k $$
$$ S_{k+1} = \frac{1}{3}k^3 + \frac{5}{2}k^2 + \frac{13}{6}k $$
Next, we expand the right-hand side of the formula for $n=k+1$:
$$ \frac{1}{3}(k+1)^3 + \frac{3}{2}(k+1)^2 - \frac{11}{6}(k+1) $$
$$ = \frac{1}{3}(k^3 + 3k^2 + 3k + 1) + \frac{3}{2}(k^2 + 2k + 1) - \frac{11}{6}(k+1) $$
$$ = \left(\frac{1}{3}k^3 + k^2 + k + \frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{3}{2}k^2 + 3k + \frac{3}{2}\right) - \left(\frac{11}{6}k + \frac{11}{6}\right) $$
Combining like terms:
$$ = \frac{1}{3}k^3 + \left(1 + \frac{3}{2}\right)k^2 + \left(1 + 3 - \frac{11}{6}\right)k + \left(\frac{1}{3} + \frac{3}{2} - \frac{11}{6}\right) $$
$$ = \frac{1}{3}k^3 + \frac{5}{2}k^2 + \left(\frac{24 - 11}{6}\right)k + \left(\frac{2 + 9 - 11}{6}\right) $$
$$ = \frac{1}{3}k^3 + \frac{5}{2}k^2 + \frac{13}{6}k $$
Since our expression for $S_{k+1}$ matches the expanded formula for $n=k+1$, the inductive step is complete.

By the principle of mathematical induction, the formula holds for all natural numbers $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 4. Let $a_{\mathrm{n}}=n^{2}+2 n-3$ : Find $S_{\mathrm{s}}$. -/
theorem algebra_313032 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (ha : ‚àÄ n, a n = n ^ 2 + 2 * n - 3) :
    ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, a i = (1 / 3) * n ^ 3 + (3 / 2) * n ^ 2 - (11 / 6) * n := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_313032 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (ha : ‚àÄ n, a n = n ^ 2 + 2 * n - 3) :
    ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, a i = (1 / 3) * n ^ 3 + (3 / 2) * n ^ 2 - (11 / 6) * n := by
  have h1 : ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 n, a i = (1 / 3) * n ^ 3 + (3 / 2) * n ^ 2 - (11 / 6) * n := by 
    intro n
    induction n with 
    | zero =>
      simp [Finset.sum_eq_zero]
      <;> norm_num [ha]
      <;> try { linarith }
    | succ n ih =>
      rw [Finset.sum_Icc_succ_top (by norm_num)]
      rw [ih]
      simp [ha]
      all_goals ring_nf <;> field_simp <;> ring
      <;> try { linarith }
  simpa using h1 n

soln_description:
To prove Example 3, we first provide a generalization of Example 3.
Let \( m \in \mathbf{N}, m \geqslant 2, a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}_{+} \) and \( abc = 1 \). Try to prove:
\[
\frac{1}{a^{m}(b+c)} + \frac{1}{b^{m}(c+a)} + \frac{1}{c^{m}(a+b)} \geqslant \frac{3}{2}.
\]

Analysis: Polya once said, solving a problem is to turn the problem to be solved into a problem that has already been solved. Recall the 28th IMO Preliminary Problem \({}^{[1]}\):

Given \( a, b, c \) are positive numbers, and \( a + b + c = 2S \), let \( n \) be a natural number. Then
\[
\frac{a^{n}}{b+c} + \frac{b^{n}}{c+a} + \frac{c^{n}}{a+b} \geqslant \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n-2} \cdot S^{n-1}.
\]

We can imagine using the already proven formula (3) to prove formulas (1) and (2). The key is to transform formulas (1) and (2) into the standard form of formula (3).

Proof: Since formula (1) is a special case of formula (2), we only need to prove formula (2).
Make the reciprocal substitution
\[
x = \frac{1}{a}, \quad y = \frac{1}{b}, \quad z = \frac{1}{c},
\]

then \( x, y, z > 0 \) and \( xyz = 1 \).
Let \( x + y + z = 2S \), and let the left side of formula (2) be \( M \). Noting that \( m-2 \geqslant 0 \), we have
\[
\begin{array}{l}
M = \frac{x^{m}}{\frac{1}{y} + \frac{1}{z}} + \frac{y^{m}}{\frac{1}{z} + \frac{1}{x}} + \frac{z^{m}}{\frac{1}{x} + \frac{1}{y}} \\
= \frac{x^{m-1} \cdot xyz}{y+z} + \frac{y^{m-1} \cdot xyz}{z+x} + \frac{z^{m-1} \cdot xyz}{x+y} \\
= \frac{x^{m-1}}{y+z} + \frac{y^{m-1}}{z+x} + \frac{z^{m-1}}{x+y} \geqslant \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{m-3} \cdot S^{m-2} \\
= \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{m-3} \cdot \left(\frac{x+y+z}{2}\right)^{m-2} \\
\geqslant \left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^{3-m} \cdot \left(\frac{3}{2} \sqrt[3]{xyz}\right)^{m-2} \\
= \left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^{3-m} \cdot \left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^{m-2} = \frac{3}{2}.
\end{array}
\]

The equality holds if and only if \( x = y = z \). Therefore, formula (2) is proved.
Thus, formula (1) is also proved.

soln_description:
### Part (a)
1. **Verify that $A$ is a good set:**
   - A set $M$ is good if each of its elements has exactly 4 divisors.
   - An integer $n$ has exactly 4 divisors if it is of the form $pq$ or $p^3$, where $p$ and $q$ are distinct primes.
   - Consider the elements of $A = \{2 \cdot 37, 19 \cdot 37, 29 \cdot 37\}$:
     - $2 \cdot 37 = 74$: The divisors are $\{1, 2, 37, 74\}$.
     - $19 \cdot 37 = 703$: The divisors are $\{1, 19, 37, 703\}$.
     - $29 \cdot 37 = 1073$: The divisors are $\{1, 29, 37, 1073\}$.
   - Each element has exactly 4 divisors, so $A$ is a good set.

2. **Calculate $S_A$:**
   - $S_A$ is the sum of all $4n$ divisors of the elements in $A$, where $n$ is the number of elements in $A$.
   - $A$ has 3 elements, so we need to sum the divisors of each element:
     \[
     \text{Divisors of } 74: \{1, 2, 37, 74\} \quad \Rightarrow \quad 1 + 2 + 37 + 74 = 114
     \]
     \[
     \text{Divisors of } 703: \{1, 19, 37, 703\} \quad \Rightarrow \quad 1 + 19 + 37 + 703 = 760
     \]
     \[
     \text{Divisors of } 1073: \{1, 29, 37, 1073\} \quad \Rightarrow \quad 1 + 29 + 37 + 1073 = 1140
     \]
   - Sum of all divisors:
     \[
     S_A = 114 + 760 + 1140 = 2014
     \]

### Part (b)
1. **Verify that $B$ is a good set and contains $8$:**
   - $8 = 2^3$, which has exactly 4 divisors: $\{1, 2, 4, 8\}$.
   - Therefore, $8$ can be part of a good set $B$.

2. **Show that $S_B \neq 2014$:**
   - The sum of the divisors of $8$ is:
     \[
     1 + 2 + 4 + 8 = 15
     \]
   - If $B$ is a good set, then any other element in $B$ must be of the form $pq$ or $p^3$.
   - For elements of the form $pq$:
     - The sum of the divisors is $(p+1)(q+1)$, which is even since $p$ and $q$ are distinct primes.
   - For elements of the form $p^3$:
     - The sum of the divisors is $1 + p + p^2 + p^3$, which is odd if $p$ is odd.
   - Since $8$ is in $B$, the sum of the divisors of $8$ is $15$, which is odd.
   - Therefore, the total sum $S_B$ must be odd.
   - Since $2014$ is even, $S_B \neq 2014$.
informal_statement:
We call a nonempty set $M$ good if its elements are positive integers, each
having exactly $4$ divisors. If the good set $M$ has $n$ elements, we denote by
$S_{M}$ the sum of all $4n$ divisors of its members (the sum may contain
repeating terms).

a) Prove that $A=\{2\cdot37,19\cdot37,29\cdot37\}$ is good and $S_{A}=2014$.

b) Prove that if the set $B$ is good and $8\in B$, then $S_{B}\neq2014$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def isGood (M : Finset ‚Ñï) : Prop :=
  M.Nonempty ‚àß ‚àÄ m ‚àà M, m > 0 ‚àß m.divisors.card = 4

/- We call a nonempty set $M$ good if its elements are positive integers, each
having exactly $4$ divisors. If the good set $M$ has $n$ elements, we denote by
$S_{M}$ the sum of all $4n$ divisors of its members (the sum may contain
repeating terms).

a) Prove that $A=\{2\cdot37,19\cdot37,29\cdot37\}$ is good and $S_{A}=2014$.

b) Prove that if the set $B$ is good and $8\in B$, then $S_{B}\neq2014$. -/
theorem number_theory_71598 {A B : Finset ‚Ñï}
    (hA : A = {2 * 37, 19 * 37, 29 * 37}) (hB : isGood B)
    (h8 : 8 ‚àà B) :
    isGood A ‚àß ‚àë m ‚àà A, m.divisors.sum id = 2014 ‚àß
    ¬¨(isGood B ‚àß ‚àë m ‚àà B, m.divisors.sum id = 2014) := by

soln_description:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve given by an equation in polar coordinates is determined by the formula

$L=\int_{\varphi_{0}}^{\varphi_{1}} \sqrt{(\rho(\varphi))^{2}+\left(\rho^{\prime}(\varphi)\right)^{2}} d \varphi$

For the curve given by the equation $\rho=6(1+\sin \varphi)$, we find: $\rho^{\prime}=6 \cos \varphi$

We obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \sqrt{(6(1+\sin \varphi))^{2}+(6 \cos \varphi)^{2}} d \varphi= \\
& =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \sqrt{36(1+\sin \varphi)^{2}+36 \cos ^{2} \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =6 \int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \sqrt{1+2 \sin \varphi+\sin ^{2} \varphi+\cos ^{2} \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =6 \int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \sqrt{2+2 \sin \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =6 \sqrt{2} \int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \sqrt{1+\sin \varphi} d \varphi= \\
& =6 \sqrt{2} \int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \sqrt{2 \cos { }^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\varphi}{2}\right)} d \varphi= \\
& =12 \int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\varphi}{2}\right) d \varphi= \\
& =12 \cdot-2 \int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\varphi}{2}\right) d\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\varphi}{2}\right)= \\
& =-\left.24 \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\varphi}{2}\right)\right|_{-\pi / 2} ^{0}=-24\left(\sin \frac{\pi}{4}-\sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{-\pi}{4}\right)\right)=-24\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}-1\right)=12(2-\sqrt{2})
\end{aligned}
$$

Source ‚Äî ¬´http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ\ÔøΩ \%D0\%9A\%D1\%83 \%D0\%B7\%D0\%BD\%D0\%B5\%D1\%86\%D0\%BE\%D0\%B2_\%D0\%98\%D0\%BD\%D1\%82\%D0\%B5\%D0\%B3\%D1\%80\%D0\%B0 $\% \mathrm{D} 0 \% \mathrm{BB} \% \mathrm{D} 1 \% 8 \mathrm{~B}+19-16$ ¬ª

informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=6(1+\sin \varphi),-\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \varphi \leq 0
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by the equations in polar coordinates.

$$
\rho=6(1+\sin \varphi),-\frac{\pi}{2} \leq \varphi \leq 0
$$ -/
theorem calculus_147254 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : f = Œª Œ∏ => 6 * (1 + sin Œ∏)) :
    ‚à´ Œ∏ in (-œÄ/2)..0, sqrt ((deriv f Œ∏)^2 + f Œ∏^2) = 12 * (2 - sqrt 2) := by

informal_statement:
For positive real numbers $a, b, c, d$, prove that the following inequality holds:
$$\dfrac{ab}{a+b} + \dfrac{cd}{c+d} \leq \dfrac{(a+c)(b+d)}{a+b+c+d}$$
informal_proof:
Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers. We want to prove the inequality:
$$ \dfrac{ab}{a+b} + \dfrac{cd}{c+d} \leq \dfrac{(a+c)(b+d)}{a+b+c+d} $$
This inequality is equivalent to showing that the following expression is less than or equal to zero:
$$ \dfrac{ab}{a+b} + \dfrac{cd}{c+d} - \dfrac{(a+c)(b+d)}{a+b+c+d} \leq 0 $$
Since $a, b, c, d$ are all positive, the sums $a+b$, $c+d$, and $a+b+c+d$ are also strictly positive. This allows us to combine the terms on the left-hand side into a single fraction with a positive denominator.

The common denominator is $(a+b)(c+d)(a+b+c+d)$. Let's express the left-hand side with this denominator:
$$ \frac{ab(c+d)(a+b+c+d) + cd(a+b)(a+b+c+d) - (a+c)(b+d)(a+b)(c+d)}{(a+b)(c+d)(a+b+c+d)} $$
The denominator is a product of positive terms, so it is strictly positive. To prove that the fraction is non-positive, we only need to show that the numerator is non-positive.

Let $N$ be the numerator:
$$ N = ab(c+d)(a+b+c+d) + cd(a+b)(a+b+c+d) - (a+c)(b+d)(a+b)(c+d) $$
We can factor the first two terms:
$$ N = \big(ab(c+d) + cd(a+b)\big)(a+b+c+d) - (a+c)(b+d)(a+b)(c+d) $$
Expanding the factors within the parentheses gives:
\begin{align*} N &= (abc+abd+acd+bcd)(a+b+c+d) \\ & \quad - (ab+ad+bc+cd)(ac+ad+bc+bd) \end{align*}
Let's expand both products.
The first product expands to:
\begin{align*} (abc+abd+acd+bcd)(a+b+c+d) = & \phantom{+} a^2bc + a^2bd + a^2cd + ab^2c + ab^2d \\ & + b^2cd + abc^2 + ac^2d + bc^2d + abd^2 \\ & + acd^2 + bcd^2 + 4abcd \end{align*}
The second product expands to:
\begin{align*} (ab+ad+bc+cd)(ac+ad+bc+bd) = & \phantom{+} a^2bc + a^2bd + ab^2c + ab^2d + a^2cd \\ & + a^2d^2 + abcd + abd^2 + abc^2 + abcd \\ & + b^2c^2 + b^2cd + ac^2d + acd^2 + bc^2d + bcd^2 \\ = & \phantom{+} a^2bc + a^2bd + a^2cd + ab^2c + ab^2d \\ & + b^2cd + abc^2 + ac^2d + bc^2d + abd^2 \\ & + acd^2 + bcd^2 + a^2d^2 + b^2c^2 + 2abcd \end{align*}
Subtracting the second expansion from the first, most terms cancel out, leaving:
$$ N = (4abcd) - (a^2d^2 + b^2c^2 + 2abcd) $$
$$ N = 2abcd - a^2d^2 - b^2c^2 $$
Rearranging this expression reveals a perfect square:
$$ N = -(a^2d^2 - 2abcd + b^2c^2) = -(ad - bc)^2 $$
For any real numbers $a, b, c, d$, the square $(ad - bc)^2$ is always non-negative. Therefore, the numerator $N = -(ad - bc)^2$ is always non-positive ($N \leq 0$).

Since the numerator is non-positive and the denominator is strictly positive, their quotient is non-positive.
$$ \frac{-(ad - bc)^2}{(a+b)(c+d)(a+b+c+d)} \leq 0 $$
This confirms the rearranged inequality, and thus the original inequality holds.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- For positive real numbers $a, b, c, d$, prove that the following inequality holds:
$$\dfrac{ab}{a+b} + \dfrac{cd}{c+d} \leq \dfrac{(a+c)(b+d)}{a+b+c+d}$$ -/
theorem inequalities_8645 (a b c d : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d) :
    a * b / (a + b) + c * d / (c + d) ‚â§ (a + c) * (b + d) / (a + b + c + d) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_8645 (a b c d : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d) :
    a * b / (a + b) + c * d / (c + d) ‚â§ (a + c) * (b + d) / (a + b + c + d) := by
  have h1 : 0 < a + b := by linarith 
  have h2 : 0 < c + d := by linarith 
  have h3 : 0 < a + b + c + d := by linarith 
  have h4 : a * b / (a + b) + c * d / (c + d) - (a + c) * (b + d) / (a + b + c + d) ‚â§ 0 := by
    have numerator_le_zero : a * b * (c + d) * (a + b + c + d) + c * d * (a + b) * (a + b + c + d) - (a + c) * (b + d) * (a + b) * (c + d) ‚â§ 0 := by 
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a * c - b * d), sq_nonneg (a * d - b * c), sq_nonneg (a * d - c * b), sq_nonneg (a - c), sq_nonneg (b - d), sq_nonneg (a * c - b * c), sq_nonneg (a * b - c * d), sq_nonneg (a + c - (b + d)), mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos ha hc, mul_pos ha hd, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos hb hd, mul_pos hc hd]
    have h6 : 0 < (a + b) * (c + d) * (a + b + c + d) := by positivity
    have h7 : a * b / (a + b) + c * d / (c + d) - (a + c) * (b + d) / (a + b + c + d) 
      = (a * b * (c + d) * (a + b + c + d) + c * d * (a + b) * (a + b + c + d) - (a + c) * (b + d) * (a + b) * (c + d)) / ((a + b) * (c + d) * (a + b + c + d)) := by 
      field_simp
      ring
    rw [h7]
    apply div_nonpos_of_nonpos_of_nonneg
    linarith 
    all_goals linarith 
    all_goals nlinarith
  linarith

soln_description:
Solution. Since

$$
\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{i}{2}, \quad\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{4}=\frac{-1}{4}, \quad\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{8}=\frac{1}{16}
$$

we have

$$
A=\left(1+\frac{1+i}{2}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{2}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{4}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{8}\right)=\frac{1}{2}(3+i) \frac{1}{2}(2+i) \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{17}{16}=\frac{255}{256}(1+i)
$$
informal_statement:
2. Simplify the expression

$$
A=\left(1+\frac{1+i}{2}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{2}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{4}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{8}\right)
$$

( $i$ is the imaginary unit)
informal_proof:
We are asked to simplify the expression for $A$:
$$ A=\left(1+\frac{1+i}{2}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{2}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{4}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{8}\right) $$
Our goal is to show that $A = \frac{255}{256}(1+i)$. We will do this by direct computation.

Let $z = \frac{1+i}{2}$. The expression for $A$ can be written as:
$$ A = (1+z)(1+z^2)(1+z^4)(1+z^8) $$

First, we compute the necessary powers of $z$:
\begin{itemize}
    \item $z^2 = \left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{1^2 + 2(1)(i) + i^2}{4} = \frac{1 + 2i - 1}{4} = \frac{2i}{4} = \frac{i}{2}$.
    \item $z^4 = (z^2)^2 = \left(\frac{i}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{i^2}{4} = \frac{-1}{4}$.
    \item $z^8 = (z^4)^2 = \left(\frac{-1}{4}\right)^2 = \frac{1}{16}$.
\end{itemize}

Now, we substitute these values back into the factors of the expression for $A$:
\begin{itemize}
    \item The first factor is $1+z = 1 + \frac{1+i}{2} = \frac{2}{2} + \frac{1+i}{2} = \frac{3+i}{2}$.
    \item The second factor is $1+z^2 = 1 + \frac{i}{2} = \frac{2+i}{2}$.
    \item The third factor is $1+z^4 = 1 + \left(\frac{-1}{4}\right) = 1 - \frac{1}{4} = \frac{3}{4}$.
    \item The fourth factor is $1+z^8 = 1 + \frac{1}{16} = \frac{17}{16}$.
\end{itemize}

Finally, we multiply these four factors together:
$$ A = \left(\frac{3+i}{2}\right) \left(\frac{2+i}{2}\right) \left(\frac{3}{4}\right) \left(\frac{17}{16}\right) $$
Let's first multiply the complex terms:
$$ \left(\frac{3+i}{2}\right) \left(\frac{2+i}{2}\right) = \frac{(3+i)(2+i)}{4} = \frac{6 + 3i + 2i + i^2}{4} = \frac{6 + 5i - 1}{4} = \frac{5+5i}{4} = \frac{5(1+i)}{4} $$
Now, we multiply this result by the remaining real factors:
$$ A = \left(\frac{5(1+i)}{4}\right) \left(\frac{3}{4}\right) \left(\frac{17}{16}\right) = \frac{5 \cdot 3 \cdot 17}{4 \cdot 4 \cdot 16} (1+i) $$
$$ A = \frac{255}{256} (1+i) $$
This completes the calculation and verifies the equality.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- 2. Simplify the expression

$$
A=\left(1+\frac{1+i}{2}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{2}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{4}\right)\left(1+\left(\frac{1+i}{2}\right)^{8}\right)
$$

( $i$ is the imaginary unit) -/
theorem algebra_251911 {A : ‚ÑÇ} (hA : A = (1 + (1 + I) / 2) * (1 + ((1 + I) / 2)^2) *
  (1 + ((1 + I) / 2)^4) * (1 + ((1 + I) / 2)^8)) :
  A = 255 / 256 * (1 + I) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

theorem algebra_251911 {A : ‚ÑÇ} (hA : A = (1 + (1 + I) / 2) * (1 + ((1 + I) / 2)^2) *
  (1 + ((1 + I) / 2)^4) * (1 + ((1 + I) / 2)^8)) :
  A = 255 / 256 * (1 + I) := by
    rw [hA]
    field_simp [Complex.ext_iff, pow_two, pow_succ, Complex.add_re, Complex.add_im, Complex.mul_re, Complex.mul_im, Complex.I_re, Complex.I_im]
    <;> norm_num [Complex.ext_iff]
    all_goals norm_num
    all_goals field_simp [Complex.ext_iff, pow_two, pow_succ, Complex.add_re, Complex.add_im, Complex.mul_re, Complex.mul_im, Complex.I_re, Complex.I_im]
    <;> norm_num [Complex.ext_iff]

soln_description:
Solution (Viviane): We consider $n$ even and $n$ odd individually.

Case 1: $n$ is even:

$n$ cannot be 2. If $n>2$, $n$ has the divisors 1,2 and $n / 2$. It follows that $1+4+(n / 2)^{2} \leq$ $5(n+1)$. Transforming gives $n \leq 20$. Testing the cases gives the solution $n=16$.

Case 2: $n$ is odd:

One is not a solution. The right-hand side is even, so the left-hand side is even. All divisors of $n$ are odd. It follows that $n$ has an odd number of divisors (with itself), so $n$ is a square number. Powers of odd prime numbers are not solutions, because then the left-hand side is $\equiv 1 \operatorname{modulo} p$ and the right-hand side is $\equiv 5 \bmod p$. This only works if $0 \equiv 4 \bmod p$, i.e. $p=2$, i.e. $n$ even.

We can therefore write $n=(p s)^{2}$, where $p$ is the smallest prime divisor of $n$ and $s$ has at least one prime divisor $\neq p$. It follows that $n$ has the three different divisors $1, p$ and $p s^{2}$. In addition, $p$ and $s$ are odd and not one, so both are greater than 2. Therefore, the following must apply

$$
5+9(p s)^{2}=1+4+9(p s)^{2} \leq 1+p^{2}+s^{2}(p s)^{2} \leq 5\left((p s)^{2}+1\right)
$$

which is not possible.

So $n=16$ is the only solution.

Other solutions are, for example, if you first limit the number of divisors towards the top and then make case distinctions, or if you estimate the number of different prime divisors and then make case distinctions.

Marking Scheme: Points for different solution paths are not additive, you get points for the solution path where you got furthest.

- Points for MuL√∂:
- $n$ even: 1 point for $n \leq 20$, then 1 point for $n=16$.
- $n$ odd: 1 point for $n$ square number, then 1 point for $n$ no prime power, 5 points if case $n$ odd in total.
- Points if the number of divisors is estimated:
- less than 16 divisors: 1 point
- less than 8 divisors: 2 points (not additive to 1 point)
- $n$ no prime power: 1 point
- Points if you estimate prime divisors:
- $n$ no prime power: 1 point
- $n$ two different prime divisors: 3 points
- $n$ more than two different prime divisors: 2 points
informal_statement:
7. find all natural numbers $n$ such that

$$
\sum_{\substack{d \mid n \\ 1 \leq d<n}} d^{2}=5(n+1)
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. find all natural numbers $n$ such that

$$
\sum_{\substack{d \mid n \\ 1 \leq d<n}} d^{2}=5(n+1)
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_266385 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    ‚àë d in (n.divisors.filter (fun x => 1 ‚â§ x ‚àß x < n)), d^2 = 5 * (n + 1) ‚Üî n = 16 := by

informal_statement:
Comparing the fractions ${ }^{111110} / 111111,{ }^{222221 / 222223},{ }^{333331} /{ }_{333334}$, arrange them in ascending order.

#
informal_proof:
To arrange the fractions in ascending order, we need to prove two inequalities:
1.  $111110 / 111111 < 333331 / 333334$
2.  $333331 / 333334 < 222221 / 222223$

We will prove each of these in turn.

**Part 1: Proving $111110 / 111111 < 333331 / 333334$**

To compare the two fractions, we can cross-multiply their numerators and denominators. Since the denominators are positive, the direction of the inequality is preserved. We must show that:
$111110 \times 333334 < 333331 \times 111111$

Let's compute the products on both sides:
- The left-hand side is $111110 \times 333334 = 37037037040$.
- The right-hand side is $333331 \times 111111 = 37037041041$.

Comparing these two results, we see that $37037037040 < 37037041041$. Thus, the first inequality holds.

**Part 2: Proving $333331 / 333334 < 222221 / 222223$**

Similarly, for the second inequality, we cross-multiply to show that:
$333331 \times 222223 < 222221 \times 333334$

Let's compute these products:
- The left-hand side is $333331 \times 222223 = 74073855553$.
- The right-hand side is $222221 \times 333334 = 74074000014$.

Comparing these two results, we see that $74073855553 < 74074000014$. Thus, the second inequality also holds.

Since both inequalities are true, we have established the ascending order:
$$ \frac{111110}{111111} < \frac{333331}{333334} < \frac{222221}{222223} $$
This completes the proof.
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_192648 : (111110 / 111111 : ‚Ñö) < (333331 / 333334 : ‚Ñö) ‚àß (333331 / 333334 : ‚Ñö) < (222221 / 222223 : ‚Ñö) := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ norm_num
  ¬∑ norm_num

soln_description:
6. $-\frac{3}{2}$.
Let $z=a+b \mathrm{i}\left(a, b \in \mathbf{R}, a^{2}+b^{2}=1\right)$.
Change the original equation to
$$
\left(a+b \text { i) } x^{2}+2(a-b \text { i) } x+2=0 \text {. }\right.
$$

Separating the real and imaginary parts, it is equivalent to
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a x^{2}+2 a x+2=0, \\
b x^{2}-2 b x=0 .
\end{array}\right.
$$

If $b=0$, then $a^{2}=1$.
But when $a=1$, equation (1) has no real solutions.
Thus, $a=-1$, in which case there exist real numbers $x=-1 \pm \sqrt{3}$ satisfying equations (1) and (2).
Therefore, $z=-1$ satisfies the condition.
If $b \neq 0$, from equation (2) we know $x \in\{0,2\}$, but clearly $x=0$ does not satisfy equation (1), so $x=2$.
Substituting into equation (1) yields
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a=-\frac{1}{4} \Rightarrow b= \pm \frac{\sqrt{15}}{4} \\
\Rightarrow z=\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{15} \mathrm{i}}{4} .
\end{array}
$$

In summary, the sum of all complex numbers $z$ that satisfy the condition is
$$
-1+\frac{-1+\sqrt{15} i}{4}+\frac{-1-\sqrt{15} i}{4}=-\frac{3}{2} .
$$
informal_statement:
6. Let the complex number $z$ satisfy $|z|=1$, such that the equation $z x^{2}+2 z x+2=0$ has real roots. Then the sum of such complex numbers $z$ is $\qquad$

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Let the complex number $z$ satisfy $|z|=1$, such that the equation $z x^{2}+2 z x+2=0$ has real roots. Then the sum of such complex numbers $z$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem inequalities_322035 (z : ‚ÑÇ) (hz : ‚Äñz‚Äñ = 1) (hroots : ‚àÉ x : ‚Ñù, z * x ^ 2 + 2 * z * x + 2 = 0) :
    z = -3 / 2 := by

soln_description:
1. **Determine the coefficient of friction ($\mu$):**
   - Since the box slides down the incline at a constant speed, the net force along the incline must be zero. This implies that the component of gravitational force down the incline is balanced by the frictional force.
   - The gravitational force component down the incline is \( W \sin 30^\circ \).
   - The normal force is \( W \cos 30^\circ \).
   - The frictional force is \( \mu \cdot \text{Normal force} = \mu W \cos 30^\circ \).
   - Since the box slides at constant speed, \( W \sin 30^\circ = \mu W \cos 30^\circ \).
   - Solving for \(\mu\):
     \[
     \mu = \frac{W \sin 30^\circ}{W \cos 30^\circ} = \frac{\sin 30^\circ}{\cos 30^\circ} = \tan 30^\circ = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}
     \]

2. **Set up the forces when a horizontal force \(P\) is applied:**
   - The normal force now has two components: one from the weight and one from the horizontal force.
   - The normal force is \( W \cos 30^\circ + P \cos 60^\circ \).
   - The frictional force is \( \mu \cdot \text{Normal force} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} (W \cos 30^\circ + P \cos 60^\circ) \).

3. **Balance the forces along the incline:**
   - The component of the horizontal force \(P\) along the incline is \( P \sin 60^\circ \).
   - The component of the gravitational force along the incline is \( W \sin 30^\circ \).
   - The frictional force opposes the motion up the incline.
   - The equation for constant speed up the incline is:
     \[
     P \sin 60^\circ = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} (W \cos 30^\circ + P \cos 60^\circ) + W \sin 30^\circ
     \]

4. **Substitute the trigonometric values:**
   - \(\sin 30^\circ = \frac{1}{2}\)
   - \(\cos 30^\circ = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\)
   - \(\sin 60^\circ = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\)
   - \(\cos 60^\circ = \frac{1}{2}\)

5. **Simplify the equation:**
   \[
   P \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \left( W \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + P \cdot \frac{1}{2} \right) + W \cdot \frac{1}{2}
   \]
   \[
   P \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}W}{2} + \frac{P}{2\sqrt{3}} + \frac{W}{2}
   \]
   \[
   P \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \frac{W}{2} + \frac{P}{2\sqrt{3}} + \frac{W}{2}
   \]
   \[
   P \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = W + \frac{P}{2\sqrt{3}}
   \]

6. **Solve for \(P\):**
   \[
   P \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - \frac{P}{2\sqrt{3}} = W
   \]
   \[
   P \left( \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - \frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}} \right) = W
   \]
   \[
   P \left( \frac{3 - 1}{2\sqrt{3}} \right) = W
   \]
   \[
   P \left( \frac{2}{2\sqrt{3}} \right) = W
   \]
   \[
   P \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \right) = W
   \]
   \[
   P = W \sqrt{3}
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{\sqrt{3}W}\)
informal_statement:
A box with weight $W$ will slide down a $30^\circ$ incline at constant speed under the influence of gravity and friction alone. If instead a horizontal force $P$ is applied to the box, the box can be made to move up the ramp at constant speed. What is the magnitude of $P$?

$\textbf{(A) } P = W/2 \\
\textbf{(B) }  P = 2W/\sqrt{3}\\
\textbf{(C) } P = W\\
\textbf{(D) } P = \sqrt{3}W \\
\textbf{(E) } P = 2W$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A box with weight $W$ will slide down a $30^\circ$ incline at constant speed under the influence of gravity and friction alone. If instead a horizontal force $P$ is applied to the box, the box can be made to move up the ramp at constant speed. What is the magnitude of $P$?

$\textbf{(A) } P = W/2 \\
\textbf{(B) }  P = 2W/\sqrt{3}\\
\textbf{(C) } P = W\\
\textbf{(D) } P = \sqrt{3}W \\
\textbf{(E) } P = 2W$ -/
theorem calculus_53346 (W P : ‚Ñù) (hW : W > 0) (hP : P > 0)
    (h1 : W * Real.sin (Real.pi / 6) = P * Real.cos (Real.pi / 6)) :
    P = Real.sqrt 3 * W := by

    (a + b + c + d + e) % 10 = 9 := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Let's introduce the substitution $a^{x}=y$. Then we have $f\left(y^{2}+2 y-7\right)y-5
$$

which is

$$
y^{2}+y-2>0
$$

Solving this, we get $y \in\langle-\infty,-2\rangle \cup\langle 1, \infty\rangle$, and due to the condition $\left(^{*}\right)$, we have $y \in\langle 1, \infty\rangle$.

Therefore, the original inequality is equivalent to the inequality $a^{x}>1$.

From the condition $f(0) \cdot f(1)1=a^{0}$, it follows that $x<0$.

The final solution to the given inequality is $x \in\langle-\infty, 0\rangle$.

Let $f$ be a real function with the following properties:

- $\mathcal{D}_{f}=[-4, \infty\rangle$,
- $f(0) \cdot f(1)<0$,
- the function $f$ is strictly decreasing on its entire domain and has one root.

Determine all $x \in \mathbf{R}$ for which the inequality $f\left(a^{2 x}+2 a^{x}-7\right)<f\left(a^{x}-5\right)$ holds, where $a$ is the root of the given function $f$.

theorem calculus_229902 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : f = Œª x => x ^ 2 / 2)

  x0 * sqrt (1 + x0 ^ 2) / 2 + log (x0 + sqrt (1 + x0 ^ 2)) / 2 := by

soln_description:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by parametric equations is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \sqrt{\left(x^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}+\left(y^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t
$$

Let's find the derivatives with respect to $t$ for the given curve:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x=\frac{1}{2} \cos t-\frac{1}{4} \cos 2 t ; x^{\prime}(t)=\frac{1}{4}(-2 \sin t+2 \sin 2 t)=\frac{1}{2}(\sin 2 t-\sin t) \\
& y=\frac{1}{2} \sin t-\frac{1}{4} \sin 2 t ; y^{\prime}(t)=\frac{1}{4}(2 \cos t-2 \cos 2 t)=\frac{1}{2}(\cos t-\cos 2 t)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, using the above formula, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L= & \int_{\pi / 2}^{2 \pi / 3} \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{2}(\sin 2 t-\sin t)\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2}(\cos t-\cos 2 t)\right)^{2}} d t= \\
& =\int_{\pi / 2}^{2 \pi / 3} \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\sin ^{2} 2 t-2 \sin 2 t \sin t+\sin ^{2} t+\cos ^{2} t-2 \cos 2 t \cos t+\cos ^{2} 2 t} d t= \\
& =\int_{\pi / 2}^{2 \pi / 3} \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{1-2 \sin 2 t \sin t+1-2 \cos 2 t \cos t} d t= \\
& =\int_{\pi / 2}^{2 \pi / 3} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \sqrt{1-\sin 2 t \sin t-\cos 2 t \cos t} d t= \\
& =\int_{\pi / 2}^{2 \pi / 3} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \sqrt{1-\sin t \cos t \sin t-\left(1-\sin { }^{2} t\right) \cos t} d t= \\
& =\int_{\pi / 2}^{2 \pi / 3} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \sqrt{1-\sin { }^{2} t \cos t-\cos t+\sin ^{2} t \cos t} d t= \\
& 2 \pi / 3 \\
= & \int_{\pi / 2}^{\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}} \sqrt{1-\cos t} d t=\int_{\pi / 2}^{2 \pi / 3} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \sqrt{2} \sin ^{2} d t= \\
& \int_{\pi / 2}^{2 \pi / 3} \sin \frac{t}{2} d t=\int_{\pi / 2}^{2} 2 \sin \frac{t}{2} d\left(\frac{t}{2}\right)=\left.2\left(-\cos \frac{t}{2}\right)\right|_{\pi / 2} ^{2 \pi / 3}=-2\left(\cos \frac{2 \pi}{3}-\cos \frac{\pi}{2}\right)=-2\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)=\sqrt{2}-1
\end{aligned}
$$

y=\frac{1}{2} \sin t-\frac{1}{4} \sin 2 t
\end{array}\right. \\
& \frac{\pi}{2} \leq t \leq \frac{2 \pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$ -/
theorem calculus_152385 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù)
  (hf : f = Œª t => (1/2 * cos t - 1/4 * cos (2*t), 1/2 * sin t - 1/4 * sin (2*t))) :
  ‚à´ t in (œÄ/2)..(2*œÄ/3), Real.sqrt ((deriv f t).1^2 + (deriv f t).2^2) = Real.sqrt 2 - 1 := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let the other leg and the hypotenuse of the right triangle be $x$ and $y$, respectively. By the Pythagorean theorem, we have
$y^{2}-x^{2}=n^{2}$, which can be rewritten as $(y-x)(y+x)=n^{2}$.
Solving this, we get $x=\frac{n^{2}-1}{2}, y=\frac{n^{2}+1}{2}$.

The perimeter of the triangle is $n+\frac{n^{2}-1}{2}+\frac{n^{2}+1}{2}=n+n^{2}$.
Therefore, the answer is (C).
informal_statement:
$32 \cdot 62$ A right-angled triangle has one leg of length a prime number $n$, and the other two sides are certain natural numbers. Then its perimeter is
(A) $n^{2}+1$.
(B) $n^{2}-1$.
(C) $n^{2}+n$.
(D) None of the above answers is correct.
(2nd "Jinyun Cup" Junior High School Mathematics Invitational, 1985)
